description: September 14, 2020: With Bulletin N. 262, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended the 70th session of the WHO Regional Committee for Europe (RC70), organised by the WHO Regional Office for Europe, on September 14 and 15, 2020. Representatives of 53 countries in the WHO European Region have attended. Representatives of WHO partners such as United Nations agencies and other intergovernmental organisations and regional networks, were also present. Non-State actors (NSAs) in official relations with WHO and regional NSAs accredited by the Regional Committee, have followed the webstream and had the opportunity to submit video and written statements in advance. The key health issues and future plans have been discussed, particularly on themes regarding the response to the COVID-19 pandemic and lessons learned from the pandemic, both globally and regionally.

description: From 23 April 2020, the Federal Ministry of Education, Science and Research in Austria applies special provisions to colleges and facilities for carrying out college study programmes. Special provisions relate to: The deadline of proofing mandatory additional tests; the holding of exams; the discontinuation of specific activities; the retry of an academic year; the submission of bachelor, diploma and master theses. Exams that have been taken or registered in the summer term 2020 and prior to the announcement of this policy are in accordance with these rules. The policy is slated to end on 30 September 2021.

description: From 23 April 2020, the Federal Ministry of Education, Science and Research in Austria applies special provisions to universities and teacher's colleges. Special provisions relate to: The division of the academic year; entry into force of curricula; admission periods; the notification of the continuation of studies; the taking of supplementary tests in art studies; the introductory and orientation phases of studies; the leave of absence; the deadline of study expirations at universities; courses and exams; the taking of exams by electronic means; the submission of bachelor, diploma and master theses, diploma and master theses in art studies and dissertations (also in art studies); periods of transition for studies and courses. Exams that have been taken or registered in the summer term 2020 and prior to the announcement of this policy are in accordance with these rules if without any grave flaws. The policy is slated to end on 30 September 2021. The counting of terms according to §§ 6 and 9 of this policy may also be valid following its termination if related to studies registered in the summer term 2020 and still eligible.

description:
At Austrian press conference on August 17th, Education Minister Heinz Faßmann presented the plan for reopening schools. The minister “wants” schools and childcare facilities to resume regular instruction in the fall, but has outlined measures to reduce the spread of the virus.
Schools will be coordinated with the Health Ministry’s “Corona Ampel” (traffic light) that is planned to go live this fall. Some measures:
- Sick children should stay home.
- Windows in classrooms will be opened for at least five minutes every 20 minutes, even once temperatures grow colder during fall and winter.
- Masks must be worn upon entering and exiting school buildings, but are not required inside classrooms.
- Teachers will be provided with FFP2 masks and receive a flu shot.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Regular cleaning and sanitary procedures applied to classrooms (e.g. classrooms must be aired out after each class) ,Special provisions exist for how teaching is done which applies to some teachers,Special provisions for all students in a school (e.g. students in primary school do not have to social distance),Other conditions not listed above (please provide detail in the text entry)

description:
On September 3, 2020, an Austrian school regulation created a traffic light system for conditions of school operation and closure, based on infection rates in the school and households of pupils. 

The green phase is the least restrictive, with measures such as holding classes outside wherever possible. 

In the yellow phase, additional conditions apply. All people on school premises must wear face coverings in hallways and common rooms. Lessons for wind instruments must be held outdoors, and singing lessons must take place either outdoors or indoors with face coverings. 

The orange phase includes aforementioned rules, plus additional rules. School events are not allowed. School management may schedule classes to begin at different times to avoid congregations of people. No singing or wind instrument lessons may take place indoors. Sports lessons must take place outside where possible, or indoors with social distancing. The number of hours in compulsory subjects may not exceed ten. Temporary offsite lessons must be provided temporarily for grades 9 and above. 

During the red phase, temporary offsite lessons must be provided for all grades. 

Different end dates apply to different provisions of the regulation.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
institution_status: Primary Schools allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Regular cleaning and sanitary procedures applied to classrooms (e.g. classrooms must be aired out after each class),Physical classroom hours or meeting times reduced (e.g. classes only meet in the morning; classes meet every other day),School event cancelled or postponed,Full remote/distance learning (e.g. All teachers must tele-teach.)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Education,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: The Ministry of Education launched a "cluster buster bus" project started for schools in Vienna, providing test result in one hour. As a supplement to other measures in the fight against the coronavirus, the bus is on its way from September 24, 2020. The new test concept works as follows: If a school reports one or more suspicious cases to the specially set up telephone number of the Vienna Health Authority, it sends a mobile team including a school doctor on the way after consultation with the responsible office in the ministry. Students who are with a negative test result are allowed to stay at school, the rest of them have to go home.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
institution_status: Primary Schools allowed to open with conditions

description: The Ministry of Education launched a "cluster buster bus" project started for schools in Vienna, providing test result in one hour. As a supplement to other measures in the fight against the coronavirus, the bus is on its way from September 24, 2020. The new test concept works as follows: If a school reports one or more suspicious cases to the specially set up telephone number of the Vienna Health Authority, it sends a mobile team including a school doctor on the way after consultation with the responsible office in the ministry. Students who are with a negative test result are allowed to stay at school, the rest of them have to go home.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: From 2 October 2020, the Federal Ministry of Education, Science and Research in Austria applies special provisions to universities and teacher's colleges. Special provisions relate to: The division of the academic year; entry into force of curricula; admission periods; the notification of the continuation of studies; the taking of supplementary tests in art studies; the introductory and orientation phases of studies; the leave of absence; the deadline of study expirations at universities; courses and exams; the taking of exams by electronic means; the submission of bachelor, diploma and master theses, diploma and master theses in art studies and dissertations (also in art studies); periods of transition for studies and courses; teacher's colleges in the winter term 2020/2021. Exams that have been taken or registered prior to the announcement of this policy are in accordance with these rules if without any grave flaws. The policy is slated to end on 30 September 2021. The counting of terms according to §§ 6 and 9 of this policy may also be valid following its termination if related to studies registered in the summer term 2020 and still eligible.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Higher education institutions (i.e. degree granting institutions)

description: The Federal Ministry of Education announced that from 8 February, 2021 primary schools start after the semester break with full face-to-face teaching. In the secondary level 1, there is a shift operation with two equally large groups of students. Group A is in school on Monday and Tuesday, group B on Wednesday and Thursday. On the other days, work assignments have to be completed. Here, too, tests are carried out on Monday and Wednesday. On Friday, as before, distance learning is on the program for everyone. Group B begins the following week. The lower school students must also wear mouth and nose protection in their classroom. High school students, however, have to wear an FFP2 mask instead of mouth and nose protection. Tests are carried out twice a week, without a negative test, students cannot come to school. Only those students who also take a test can take part in face-to-face lessons.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: On August 25, 2021, Austria enacted a school regulation that requires proof of vaccination and testing for school teachers, administrative staff, and students. Teachers and administrative staff must either provide proof of vaccination against COVID-19, or proof of a negative coronavirus test at least once per week. Voluntary testing must be available for students as often as is necessary to demonstrate a low epidemiological risk level every day. The policy applies only to the academic year of 2021/2022, which began on November 1, 2021. UPDATE: The original policy required teachers and administrative staff to show proof of vaccination. This has been changed to proof of a second vaccination dose at least 22 days and no more than 270 days prior.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On August 25, 2021, the Austrian government announced a school regulation that would enable a school board to require any of the following measures for a particular school: (1) face coverings, (2) SARS-CoV-2 testing as a condition of classroom participation, and (3) a delayed start of classes. description: On August 25, 2021, the Austrian government announced a school regulation concerning air quality. For activities involving singing, playing woodwind instruments, and physical activities like sports, additional ventilation is required, as determined by an individual school's hygiene plan. These activities should take place outside whenever possible. When outdoor activity is not possible, students must remain at least two meters apart when playing music, and one meter apart when playing sports, unless like sport required physical contact. The policy applies to the academic year 2021/2022, which began on November 1, 2021, and will end around July 9, 2022.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)

description: On August 25, 2021, the Austrian government announced a school regulation requiring a three-week safety phase at the beginning of the academic year 2021/2022. During this phase, pupils, teachers, and administrative staff must (1) wear face coverings in hallways and common areas (not classrooms); (2) provide proof of negative coronavirus tests at least once per week, or as often as necessary to demonstrate low epidemiological risk. Teachers and administrative staff are exempt from the testing requirement if they provide proof of vaccination against COVID-19. The policy applies to the academic year 2021/2022, which began on November 1, 2021, and will end around July 9, 2022.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description: On August 25, 2021, Austria enacted a school regulation that requires proof of vaccination and testing for school teachers, administrative staff, and students. Teachers and administrative staff must either provide proof of vaccination against COVID-19, or proof of a negative coronavirus test at least once per week. Voluntary testing must be available for students as often as is necessary to demonstrate a low epidemiological risk level every day. The policy applies only to the academic year of 2021/2022, which began on November 1, 2021.

The plan must include strategies and procedures for ensuring sufficient ventilation; the preparation of infrastructure (e.g., using additional rooms for school purposes); risk analysis guidelines for school events, arrangements for the provision and storage of face coverings, testing materials, and disinfectants; and instruction at different risk levels. description: On August 25, 2021, the Austrian government announced an order requiring schools to allow delayed or repeated examinations. Up to two late exams for the summer semester of the academic year 2019/2020, or the entire academic year 2020/2021, may be taken or repeated up to November 30, 2021. Students with more than two failed or foregone exams from the year 2020/2021 may advance to the next school level, unless they do not pass the requisite number of exams by November 30, 2021.

description: On the 27th of January, Austria set up a priorisation scheme for COVID 19 vaccines. The policy decreed that people older than 80 and those with disabilities and their assistants were to be vaccinated first. From February 1st, people older than 65, people that otherwise formed part of a risk group, people in 24 hour care as well as their caretakers and people who live in a household with pregnant women, could also be vaccinated. In the case that there is sufficient serum and it cannot be used to vaccinate those more at risk in a timely manner, all people with health insurance can be vaccinated as well. Vaccination is provided by the nationstate.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Distribution (shipping; storage; administration) of COVID-19 vaccines

description: An Austrian health ministry order created a priority list for COVID-19 vaccinations administered by primary care doctors that went into effect on January 28, 2021, and was set to expire on September 30, 2021. The highest priority group, whose eligibility began on January 28, 2021, includes (1) persons over the age of 80, and (2) persons with disabilities and their carers. The second priority group, whose eligibility began on February 1, 2021, includes (1) persons at least 65 years in age, (2) persons in specified high-risk groups, (3) persons in 24-hour care, their carers, and people in their households, and (4) persons living in the same household as a pregnant person.

description: An Austrian health ministry order created a priority list for COVID-19 vaccinations administered by primary care doctors that went into effect on January 28, 2021, and was set to expire on September 30, 2021. The highest priority group, whose eligibility began on January 28, 2021, includes (1) persons over the age of 80, and (2) persons with disabilities and their carers. The second priority group, whose eligibility began on February 1, 2021, includes (1) persons at least 65 years in age, (2) persons in specified high-risk groups, (3) persons in 24-hour care, their carers, and people in their households, and (4) persons living in the same household as a pregnant person. UPDATE: Effective February 12, 2021, two new vaccination priority groups were created. The newly created third-highest priority group, eligible for vaccination on February 15, 2021, includes health care professionals and persons engaged in outpatient (home) care. The newly created fourth-highest priority group, eligible for vaccination on March 15, 2021, includes staff in schools, kindergartens, crèches, and childcare facilities.

description: An Austrian policy went into effect on March 1, 2021 states that marketers of medicinal products related to COVID-19 (implicating COVID-19 vaccines) may apply for government authorization to market such products past their expiration dates to hospital if there is an unmet demand in the Austrian population, no suitable alternatives, and no risk to patients. description: From March 11, 2020, Austria obligates persons who want to enter Austria from Italy to carry a medical certificate in German, English or Italian and show that the molecular biological test for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. The medical certificate cannot be older than four days upon entry. If failing to do so, persons can be denied entry. Austrian citizens or those with their main, secondary or habitual residence in Austria are allowed to enter but are obliged to commence immediately with a 14-day self-monitored home quarantine. Additionally, transit through Austria is permitted without a stopover, provided that the exit is ensured. Freight, commercial and commuter traffic is also exempted from this policy. The policy is in place until May 31, 2020. UPDATE: The original policy was to expire May 7, it has been extended to May 31. UPDATE: The original policy was to expire May 7, it has been extended to May 31.

description: From 18 March 2020, the Federal Ministry of Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria prohibits passenger aircrafts departing from the People's Republic of China, Republic of Korea, Islamic Republic of Iran, Italy, Switzerland, France, Spain, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, the Russian Federation and Ukraine from landing in Austria for two weeks. Exceptions exist. The policy is slated to end on March 22. UPDATE: From 30 April 2020, the Republic of Korea is no longer affected by these restrictions. Exceptions are extended and now also include flights for transporting seasonal workers in the agricultural and silvicultural sectors as well as nursing and health personnel in compliance with § 1 of the "Verordnung über die Einreise auf dem Luftweg nach Österreich" (BGBl. II Nr. 105/2020, Version BGBl. II Nr. 196/2020). Landing restrictions are extended to May 22. UPDATE: From 30 April 2020, the Republic of Korea is no longer affected by these restrictions. update_level_var: [travel_mechanism] of policy relaxing ; [compliance] of policy relaxing ; timing of policy strengthening
description: From 14 April 2020, the Federal Ministry of Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that persons who want to enter Austria from bordering countries are obligated to carry a medical certificate in German, English, Italian or French which shows that molecular biological tests for SARS-CoV-2 were negative. The medical certificate cannot be older than four days upon entry. If failing to do so, persons can be denied entry. Exceptions exist. The policy is slated to end on April 30. UPDATE: From 1 May 2020, the applicability of this policy to entries by land is made explicit. Exceptions for entering Austria are extended to those that are "necessarily to be enabled" to enter Austria if directly applicable to provisions of constitutional and Union law. Seasonal workers in the agricultural and silvicultural sectors as well as nursing and health personnel are allowed to enter Austria by rail or bus if there are no halts in between. An obligatory quarantine for 14 days also applies to these individuals. The municipalities of Vomp-Hinterriss, Mittelberg and Jungholz are now exempted. Those in need of serious medical assistance in Austria can, in addition to having an Austrian citizenship or being covered by a medical or private insurance in Austria, be exempted if they can submit a treatment assurance by an Austrian hospital related to exceptional medical reasons. The policy now also does not explicitly apply to public transport passengers if, in the case of travelling through foreign territory, there are no halts in between. Entry restrictions are extended to May 31. UPDATE: From 1 May 2020, the applicability of this policy to entries by land is made explicit. Exceptions for entering Austria are extended to those that are "necessarily to be enabled" to enter Austria if directly applicable to provisions of constitutional and Union law. Seasonal workers in the agricultural and silvicultural sectors as well as nursing and health personnel are allowed to enter Austria by rail or bus if there are no halts in between. An obligatory quarantine for 14 days also applies to these individuals. The municipalities of Vomp-Hinterriss, Mittelberg and Jungholz are now exempted. Those in need of serious medical assistance in Austria can, in addition to having an Austrian citizenship or being covered by a medical or private insurance in Austria, be exempted if they can submit a treatment assurance by an Austrian hospital related to exceptional medical reasons. The policy now also does not explicitly apply to public transport passengers if, in the case of travelling through foreign territory, there are no halts in between. Entry restrictions are extended to May 31.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Austrian Airlines will take to the air again on June 15. For the beginning, direct flights to ten destinations within or close to Europe will resume. All tickets can be rebooked flexibly and higher hygiene standards (e.g. mandatory masks for travelers, higher frequency of disinfection etc.) apply throughout the check-in process and flight. The following destinations can be reached from Vienna in the first week of the restart (June 15-21):
Amsterdam, Athens, Basel, Berlin, Brussels, Bucharest, Dubrovnik, Düsseldorf, Frankfurt, Geneva, Hamburg, Copenhagen, Larnaka, London, Munich, Paris, Prishtina, Sarajevo, Skopje, Sofia, Stockholm, Stuttgart, Tel Aviv, Thessaloniki, Tirana, Varna und Zurich.

In the second week (June 22-28), Belgrade, Graz, Innsbruck, Kiyv, Kosice, Milan, Nice, Prague, Split und Warsaw are to follow.

description: From 4 June 2020, the Federal Ministry of Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that persons who want to enter Austria by land or water from foreign countries outside of Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Germany, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Hungary or Slovenia are obligated to carry a medical certificate in German, English, Italian or French which shows that molecular biological tests for SARS-CoV-2 were negative. The medical certificate cannot be older than four days upon entry. The guidelines that apply to medical certificates are renewed when compared to before. If failing to do so, persons can be denied entry. Exceptions are changed and extended when compared to the regulatory situation of May 28. The policy is slated to end on June 15. UPDATE: It expired on June 15. UPDATE: It expired on June 15.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: From 4 June 2020, the Federal Ministry of Internal Affairs in Austria, in order to ensure "public tranquility, order and safety", temporarily reintroduces border controls by land and water on the internal borders with the Republic of Italy, the Republic of Slovenia and Hungary. Borders may only be crossed at certain border crossing points. The policy is slated to end on June 15 and, for the Republic of Slovenia and Hungary, November 11, respectively. UPDATE: Border controls by Austria on its internal borders with the Republic of Italy expired on June 15. UPDATE: Border controls by Austria on its internal borders with the Republic of Italy expired on June 15.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
From June 16, Austria permits again travels to and from 31 European countries. Travelers do not need to go into quarantine or present a coronavirus test result when traveling to Austria from these countries. Different rules may still apply for entering some of these countries coming from Austria. The 31 countries are:

Belgium, Bulgaria, Denmark and the Färöer islands, Germany, Estonia, Finland, France, Greece, Iceland, Ireland, Italy (a travel warning is still in force for the province of Lombardy), Croatia, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Romania, Switzerland, Cyprus and the micro states Andorra, Monaco, San Marino and the Vatican City.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs

description: From March 7, the Austrian government announces that "Third-country nationals who have resided in one of the countries for which a travel warning in connection with the occurrence of SARS-CoV-2 within the last 14 days prior to departure are obliged to carry to carry a certificate of their health and to show that the molecular biological test for SARS-CoV-2 is negative upon arrival" in Austria. Otherwise, the entry can be refused. UPDATE: Austria has reopened its borders to all EU countries for residents from these countries and Austrian citizens, who have not been in any other countries except those in the past 14 days. Travellers from these countries do not need to show a negative COVID-19 test or commit to quarantine. The European countries except from this are the UK, Sweden and Portugal, to and from which non-essential travel is still strongly discouraged and require and health certificate and 14 days of self-monitored quarantine.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: In Austria, Anyone entering the country from one of 32 states or territories defined as having an unstable or risky COVID-19 situation has to self-quarantine at home for 14 days. If the result is negative, there is no need for home quarantine. Alternatively, travelers can also present a negative test result not older than four days upon crossing the border. The countries and territories classified as risky are: Albania, Bangladesh, Belarus, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Brazil, Bulgaria, Chile, Egypt, Ecuador, India, Indonesia, Iran, Kosovo, Mexico, Moldova, Montenegro, Nigeria, Northern Macedonia, Pakistan, Peru, Philippines, Portugal, Romania, Russian Federation, Sweden, Senegal, Serbia, South Africa, Turkey, Ukraine, United States and Hubei Province (China).
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs

description:
Health Minister Rudolf Anschober (Greens) announced that starting this Thursday, July 16, planes coming from 10 countries will no longer be permitted to land in Austria due to rising coronavirus infection rates there. Including these new restrictions, Austria bans direct flight traffic with 18 countries in total. These countries are:
Belarus; China; United Kingdom; Iran; Portugal; Russia; Sweden; Ukraine; Bulgaria; Romania; Moldava; Egypt; Serbia; Bosnia & Herzegovina; North Macedonia; Albania; Kosovo; Montenegro

description:
The Austrian government issued a travel warning for the Spanish mainland, which will enter into force on Monday, August 10, 2020.
The warning is currently not valid for the Spanish islands, i.e. the Balearic islands and the Canaries.That means that travelers coming back from the Spanish mainland to Austria will have to show a negative COVID-19 test result, otherwise they need to enter a 10-day quarantine.

description: On September 6, 2020, Austria announced that EU/EEA/Swiss citizens arriving from a high-risk area are obligated to produce a medical certificate proving a negative COVID-19 PCR test that has been administered in the last 72 hours before arrival. The following are considered high-risk areas by the Austrian government: Albania, Bangladesh, Belarus, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Brazil, Bulgaria, Chile, Croatia, Ecuador, Egypt, India, Indonesia, Iran, Kosovo, Mexico, Moldavia, Montenegro, Nigeria, North Macedonia, Pakistan, Peoples Republic of China – Province Hubei, Peru, Philippines, Portugal, Romania, Russian Federation, Senegal, Serbia, South Africa, mainland Spain and the Balearic Islands, Sweden, Turkey, Ukraine and USA.

description: Austria has issued travel warnings for the Czech capital Prague and the French regions Île de France and Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur since September 24, 2020. New travel warnings have also been issued for Andorra and for the non-European countries such as Israel, Argentina, Bahrain, Kuwait, Costa Rica and the Maldives. When entering Austria from these countries, a medical health certificate with a negative Corona test must be presented which must not be older than 72 hours. Otherwise, a ten-day quarantine is mandatory.

description: On October 31, 2020, Austria has introduced new arrival requirements for travelers coming from Czechia, Belgium, and the United Kingdom. description:
Austria announced that starting from December 7, 2020 up until December 19, 2020, travelers arriving from a country with a travel warning, are required to present a negative COVID-19 PCR test taken within 72 hours of arrival, or be tested within 48 hours of arrival and self-isolate while waiting for the result. The Austrian government has designated travel warnings for the following countries:
Albania, Andorra, Argentina, Bahrain, Bangladesh, Belarus, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Brazil, Bulgaria, Chile, China (Hubei Province), Costa Rica, Croatia, Czech Republic (Prague Region), Ecuador, Egypt, France (Provence-Alpes-Cote d'Azur and Ile-de-France), India, Indonesia, Iran, Israel, Kosovo, Kuwait, Maldives, Mexico, Moldova, Montenegro, Nigeria, North Macedonia, Pakistan, Peru, Philippines, Portugal (Norte Region and Lisbon), Romania, Russian Federation, Senegal, Serbia, South Africa, Spain (mainland and Balearic Islands), Turkey, Ukraine, and the US
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
From June 16, Austria permits again travels to and from 31 European countries. Travelers do not need to go into quarantine or present a coronavirus test result when traveling to Austria from these countries. Different rules may still apply for entering some of these countries coming from Austria. The 31 countries are:

Belgium, Bulgaria, Denmark and the Färöer islands, Germany, Estonia, Finland, France, Greece, Iceland, Ireland, Italy (a travel warning is still in force for the province of Lombardy), Croatia, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Romania, Switzerland, Cyprus and the micro states Andorra, Monaco, San Marino and the Vatican City. UPDATE: Due to rising numbers in the country, a new policies on traveling to Austria applies from December 19th. Almost all countries are announced as high risk area and are not allowed to enter Austria without restrictions anymore.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs

description:
The Austrian government announced that from January 15th 2021, people entering Austria from a defined high-risk area are obligated to submit key information, in order to facilitate contact tracing. The pre-travel clearance online form serves this purpose and needs to be submitted electronically before entering the country. In exceptional cases, e.g. if someone does not have the technical means to fill out the document online, the form can also be filled out and used in printed form. 
Some exceptions exist for certain groups (e.g. regular commuters).

description:
Austria, May 1, 2021
Austria will permit those who are:
1. Humanitarian forces,
2. Persons who, for the purpose of exercising a compulsory judicial or
officially imposed duty, such as carrying out charges too
Court hearings, entry,
3. Foreigners, if they have a photo ID in accordance with Section 5 of the Official Seat Act,
Federal Law Gazette I No. 54/2021,
4. An accompanying person as part of the entry for medical reasons 
5. People who visit an international institution
6. Austrian citizens, EU / EEA citizens or Swiss citizens, or Persons with a place of residence or habitual abode in Austria.

In addition, a ten-day quarantine must be commenced immediately. 
The quarantine is deemed to have ended when a molecular biological test for SARS-CoV-2 is not carried out before the fifth day after entry and the test result is negative. 

Travelers must pay for the tests themselves.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs

may, or

description: An Austria order dated May 12, 2021 creates a special external border rule for Germany. If someone crosses into Austria from Germany, and they can credibly demonstrated that they have stayed exclusively within Germany or Austria within the last ten days, then they must carry proof of COVID-19 vaccination, recovery, negative test result, or a medical certificate and present it for possible inspection. Absent one of these things, they must present the result of a molecular biological test for SARS-CoV-2 or an antigen test within 24 hours of entry at a migration control point. The traveler is responsible for the test's cost.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: An Austria order dated May 12, 2021 creates a special external border rule for Germany. If someone crosses into Austria from Germany, and they can credibly demonstrated that they have stayed exclusively within Germany or Austria within the last ten days, then they must carry proof of COVID-19 vaccination, recovery, negative test result, or a medical certificate and present it for possible inspection. Absent one of these things, they must present the result of a molecular biological test for SARS-CoV-2 or an antigen test within 24 hours of entry at a migration control point. The traveler is responsible for the test's cost.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: People with certain health conditions (please note which health conditions in the text entry),People who have recovered and/or survived COVID-19,People who are fully vaccinated against COVID-19,People who are partially vaccinated against COVID-19,People who are not vaccinated against COVID-19
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Police

description: On June 25, Austria announced that, starting from July 1, 2021, travellers entering Austria from "low epidemiological risk" regions and states (50 countries) who have only stayed in one of such regions in the past ten days must provide a "proof of low epidemiological risk" ("Nachweise über eine geringe epidemiologische Gefahr") upon entry. If not, they must be tested for covid within 24 hours after they entered Austria. The policy is set to end on August 31, 2021

description: On June 25, Austria announced that, starting from July 1, 2021, travellers who had been in any of the virus-variant areas and states (Botswana, Brazil, Eswatini, India, Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, Namibia, Nepal, Zambia, Zimbabwe, South Africa, Uruguay and United Kingdom) in the past 10 days are prohibited from entering Austria. This, however, does not apply to Austrian citizens; EU/EEA citizens; Swizz citizens; residents of EU/EEA states or residents of Andorra, Monaco, San Marino, the Vatican or Switzerland; individuals with residence permits, documentations, or title;  diplomatic staff; international organisation staff; employees of certain corporations; students; school staff; professionals; humanitarian responders; individuals with court obligation; individuals attending important family events or with family emergency. The policy is set to end on August 31, 2021
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Travel History Form (e.g. documents where traveler has recently been)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
enforcer: National Government,Provincial/State Government,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On July 5, 2021, Austria announced that Russia is added to the list of countries considered "virus-variant" and the same restrictions would apply to it. The change in policy is in effect on July 8, 2021. On June 25, Austria announced that, starting from July 1, 2021,  travellers who had been in any of the virus-variant areas and states in the past 10 days are prohibited from entering Austria. The policy, however, does allow exemptions under certain circumstances. Those that are exempted and are permitted to enter Austria (Austrian citizens; EU/EEA citizens; Swizz citizens; residents of EU/EEA states or residents of Andorra, Monaco, San Marino, the Vatican or Switzerland; individuals with residence permits, documentations, or title; diplomatic staff; international organisation staff; employees of certain corporations; students; school staff; professionals; humanitarian responders; individuals with court obligation; individuals attending important family events or with family emergency.) must go through a 10 day quarantine upon entering the country.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Travel History Form (e.g. documents where traveler has recently been)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
enforcer: National Government,Provincial/State Government,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On July 5, Austria added "“Armenia” , “Azerbaijan” , “Bosnia and Herzegovina” , “Brunei” , “Jordan” , “Canada” , “Qatar”, “Kosovo” , “Moldova” and “Montenegro”" to the list of countries that are considered  "low epidemiological risk". Those who have only stayed in one of such regions in the past ten days must provide a "proof of low epidemiological risk" ("Nachweise über eine geringe epidemiologische Gefahr") upon entry. If not, they must be tested for covid within 24 hours after they entered Austria. The policy change is in effect on July 8, 2021 and is set to end on August 31, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On July 28, 2021, Austria announced that, starting from August 3, 2021, people entering from the Netherlands, Spain, or Cyprus by air need to provide a negative PCR test result or a proof of vaccination or approved health certificate. Individuals who have stayed in these countries in the past 10 days can now enter after providing a "proof of low epidemiological risk" and participate in quarantine for 10 days. The length of the quarantine may be shortened if on. the fifth day the individual is tested negative. People who had visited countries that are considered high risks are still prohibited from entering Austria with certain exceptions to the travel ban. The policy is in effect on August 15, 2021 and is set to end on September 30, 2021.

description: On July 5, 2021, Austria announced that Russia is added to the list of countries considered "virus-variant" and the same restrictions would apply to it. The change in policy is in effect on July 8, 2021. On June 25, Austria announced that, starting from July 1, 2021,  travellers who had been in any of the virus-variant areas and states in the past 10 days are prohibited from entering Austria. The policy, however, does allow exemptions under certain circumstances. Those that are exempted and are permitted to enter Austria (Austrian citizens; EU/EEA citizens; Swizz citizens; residents of EU/EEA states or residents of Andorra, Monaco, San Marino, the Vatican or Switzerland; individuals with residence permits, documentations, or title; diplomatic staff; international organisation staff; employees of certain corporations; students; school staff; professionals; humanitarian responders; individuals with court obligation; individuals attending important family events or with family emergency.) must go through a 10 day quarantine upon entering the country. UPDATE: On August 13, 2021, ""Botswana" , "India" , "Nepal" , "Russia" , "Zambia" , "South Africa" ​​and "United Kingdom"" are removed from the list of countries that are considered high risk. The original policy is terminated.

Those who have only stayed in one of such regions in the past ten days must provide a "proof of low epidemiological risk" ("Nachweise über eine geringe epidemiologische Gefahr") upon entry. UPDATE: On August 13, 2021, the list of country. that are considered of low epidemiological risk is updated by Austria. The change is to be in effect starting from August 15, 2021. Passengers from Spain or Cyprus by air, however, still need to provide a negative PCR test result or a proof of vaccination or approved health certificate. If no documents can be provided, a covid test must be taken at the airport or within the first 24 hours after the individual entered. The policy is set to end on September 30, 2021. UPDATE: On September 10, Austria announced that "Persons arriving by air from Cyprus shall carry a negative result of a molecular biological test, proof of vaccination, proof of recovery or a medical certificate as appropriate." The current policy is terminated.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On August 13, 2021, ""Botswana" , "India" , "Nepal" , "Russia" , "Zambia" , "South Africa" ​​and "United Kingdom"" are removed from the list of countries that are considered high risk. Individuals who have stayed in these countries in the past 10 days can now enter after providing a "proof of low epidemiological risk" and participate in quarantine for 10 days. The length of the quarantine may be shortened if on. the fifth day the individual is tested negative. People who had visited countries that are considered high risks are still prohibited from entering Austria with certain exceptions to the travel ban. The policy is in effect on August 15, 2021 and is set to end on September 30, 2021. UPDATE: On September 10, 2021, Austria changed the list of country that is considered high risk (virus variant). The change is to come into effect on September 15, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Travel History Form (e.g. documents where traveler has recently been)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On December 18, 2021, Austria announced that people who enter the country for the purpose of "regular commuting for professional purposes, to participate in school and university, for family purposes or to visit a partner" must provide a proof of vaccination and a proof of negative PCR test that was taken within 24 hours before the individuals' arrival. The policy is in effect on December 20, 2021 and is set to end on January 31, 2022.

description:
Starting January 24th, 2022, Angola, Botswana, Denmark, Eswatini, Lesotho, Malawi, Mosambique, Namibia, the Netherlands, Norway, Zambia, Zimbabwe, South Africa and the United Kingdom are no longer classified as countries with a variant of concern.
Following this, and in accordance with the "2G+" regime, only travelers with a proof of recovery or vaccination and an additional PCR negative test result can enter Austria. Those who vaccinated with a booster shot are exempt from the additional PCR testing requirement.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

Starting January 24th, 2022, Angola, Botswana, Denmark, Eswatini, Lesotho, Malawi, Mosambique, Namibia, the Netherlands, Norway, Zambia, Zimbabwe, South Africa and the United Kingdom are no longer classified as countries with a variant of concern.
Following this, and in accordance with the "2G+" regime, only travelers with a proof of recovery or vaccination and an additional PCR negative test result can enter Austria. Those who vaccinated with a booster shot are exempt from the additional PCR testing requirement.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type_sub_cat: 2G: Must be (i) either vaccinated or (ii) recovered from COVID-19
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On December 23, 2021, Austria added "United Kingdom," "Norway," "Netherlands," and "Denmark" onto the list of countries from which, if someone has stayed in one of these countries in the past 10 days, are prohibited from entering Austria. There are certain exceptions to this policy listed by the Austrian government. The change comes into effect on December 25, 2021 and is set to end on January 31, 2022. UPDATE: On January 19, 2022, Austria announced that the list to which the policy applied would be changed. The change comes into effect on January 24, 2022. This version of the policy is terminated.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
enforcer: National Government,Provincial/State Government,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On December 17, 2021, Austria announced that people who have not stayed in areas that are considered "virus-variant" in the past 10 days may enter Austria with "proof of vaccination or recovery and, in addition, a negative test result or a medical certificate". The change will be in effect on December 25, 2021 and is set to end on January 31, 2022. UPDATE: On January 19, 2022, Austria announced that the list to which the policy applied would be changed. The change comes into effect on January 24, 2022. This version of the policy is terminated.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: From February 28 2020, the Federal Ministry of Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that air carriers are required [...] to immediately report passengers who have been in an area for which a travel warning related to the occurrence of SARS-CoV-2 has been pronounced in the last 14 days before the start of the trip, and who have arrived at an airport in Austria. If passengers from countries for which a travel warning related to SARS-CoV-2 has been issued are confirmed to be infected with SARS-CoV-2, air carriers are required to immediately provide the entire passenger list. The policy is slated to end on June 30.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: A person’s absolute (e.g. GPS) location over time
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Other workers where the distinction between essential or non-essential is not explictely made (please note the occupation in the text entry)
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

As to not to undermine the data protection regulations, all of this should be done on a voluntary basis.

description: From February 28 2020, the Federal Ministry of Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that air carriers are required [...] to immediately report passengers who have been in an area for which a travel warning related to the occurrence of SARS-CoV-2 has been pronounced in the last 14 days before the start of the trip, and who have arrived at an airport in Austria. description: From February 28 2020, the Federal Ministry of Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that air carriers are required [...] to immediately report passengers who have been in an area for which a travel warning related to the occurrence of SARS-CoV-2 has been pronounced in the last 14 days before the start of the trip, and who have arrived at an airport in Austria. If passengers from countries for which a travel warning related to SARS-CoV-2 has been issued are confirmed to be infected with SARS-CoV-2, air carriers are required to immediately provide the entire passenger list. The policy is slated to end on June 30. UPDATE: From 29 June 2020, the Federal Ministry of Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria is required to make sure that passenger data is to be deleted at the end of 21 days. The policy is extended to December 31. UPDATE: From 29 June 2020, the Federal Ministry of Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria is required to make sure that passenger data is to be deleted at the end of 21 days. The policy is extended to December 31.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Who a person has come into contact with over time
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Other workers where the distinction between essential or non-essential is not explictely made (please note the occupation in the text entry)

description:
The Austrian government has established a “strategic reserve” of masks and protective gear as a reaction to the scramble for equipment at the beginning of the pandemic.
In cooperation with the Red Cross, the government purchased 2.6 million respiratory masks, 44.4 million surgical masks, 1.7 million examination gloves, 430,000 protective overalls, 37,000 protective goggles, 150,000 disposable aprons and 19,500 pulse oximeters with finger clips.
In addition, 9,000 oxygen masks, 50,000 CoV test kits and 991,000 CoV rapid tests were stored in five facilities of the Austrian Bundesheer (Federal Army).
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs

description: On February 19th, Austria prepared in a number of ways for shortages of medicine and oxygen. Issuers of medical products are, under certain conditions and given certain informations, allowed to request the issuance of products extending the expiration date. This will be tested and, if succesfull approved by the state. Furthermore, if oxygen shortages arise in connection with COVID, firms that are not officially registered for medical oxygen related business, but are approved under pharmaceutical law can bottle oxygen. Also, oxygen can be bottled in various safe containers that are not normally permitted for medical purposes.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of March 1, 2021, Austria will bewill be gradually expanded with free self-testing in pharmacies (Health resources). Up to five free tests will be available per person per month. Initially, however, only about 500,000 to 600,000 self-tests are available. By mid-March, there should be significantly more available self-tests. Pharmacies are to be supplied successively with further test kits.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 29, 2021, Vienna (Austria) Introduces New Covid-19 Testing System (Health Testing). the City of Vienna has introduced the new testing system "Alles Gurgelt!". Every Viennese is eligible to pick up PCR tests at the 152 BIPA stores throughout Vienna, record herself or himself while conducting the test and drop off the tests at one of 620 REWE locations. The results of the test is available after 24 hours and works as an "entry test" for body-related services.

The offer will be provided in conjunction with the progress being made with vaccines (Health resources - test kits).

description:
Austria's mass Covid testing scheme (health resources - test kits) is set to be phased out from March 31st, 2022, and replaced by a targeted testing program. Most regions of Austria accept at-home antigen tests as 3G proof again
Self-tests for Covid-19 will once again be accepted as 3G in all of Austria except Vienna and Lower Austria after the government updated its guidelines to allow regions and the healthcare sector to cope with a sharp rise in new cases.

description: ​​On 15 March 2022, Free Covid-19 tests (Heath Resources - Test Kits) to be limited in Austria from April. The Austrian Federal Government has revised the country’s Covid-19 strategy, including the end of unlimited free tests. From April 1st, residents in Austria will be entitled to five PCR and five antigen tests per month, departing from the unlimited free tests currently available.

description: On November 3, 2021, Reutte, a city in Austria's Tyrol state, announced that, for an individual to leave the region, they must provide a negative covid-19 test result, a proof of vaccination, or a proof of recovery (neutralizing antibodies no longer than 90 days ago is acceptable before November 7). Children under 12 years old, health emergency, public security service, rescue organizations, goods, service, and public transportation, passengers with no stopover, and people with judicial or official duty, school children and "Children who use facilities in accordance with the Tyrolean Children's Education and Child Care Act - TKKG in the area Visit § 1 or the adjacent district for the purpose visiting these facilities and for people who transport children to and from these facilities solely for the purpose of such transport; this exception applies mutatis mutandis for childcare by childminders." are exempted from this policy. "Persons not residing in an area according to § 1, for whom a positive result was determined by an antigen test for SARS-CoV-2 or a molecular biological test for SARS-CoV-2 before returning to the place of residence; However, this is only on the condition that they do so as quickly as possible - either alone with a motor vehicle or as part of a secured transport - for the purpose go into official segregation to a residence." The policy is in effect on November 5, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: From 16 March 2020, the Federal Ministry of Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering public spaces is prohibited. Exceptions exist. The policy is slated to end on March 22. UPDATE: From 20 March 2020, if protection measures for lowering the risk of infection are implemented, they may replace minimum distance provisions. Funerals within closest family circles are now exempted from lockdown restrictions. Exceptions for entering work places are now valid only if professional activities cannot be carried out outside of the work place. However, it is made explicit that professional activities are preferably to be carried out outside of the work place if possible and mutually agreed upon by employees and employers. Lockdown restrictions are extended to April 13. UPDATE: From 20 March 2020, if protection measures for lowering the risk of infection are implemented, they may replace minimum distance provisions. Funerals within closest family circles are now exempted from lockdown restrictions. Exceptions for entering work places are now valid only if professional activities cannot be carried out outside of the work place. However, it is made explicit that professional activities are preferably to be carried out outside of the work place if possible and mutually agreed upon by employees and employers. Lockdown restrictions are extended to April 13.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 16 March 2020, the Federal Ministry of Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering public spaces is prohibited. Exceptions exist. The policy is slated to end on March 22. UPDATE: From 14 April 2020, exceptions are extended and now include weddings and funerals within close family circles. The purchase of goods and services exempted from lockdown restrictions now corresponds to the provisions as per BGBl. II Nr. 96/2020 idgF. Face and nose covering in areas where usually not required through "mechanical safeguards" [probably a face mask; W.H.] must be mutually agreed upon by employees and employers. Lockdown restrictions are extended to April 30. UPDATE: From 14 April 2020, exceptions are extended and now include weddings and funerals within close family circles. description:

description: From 17 November 2020, the Federal Ministry of Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that leaving or staying outside one's private living area (which also includes living units within accommodation providers or in retirement and nursing homes as well as homes for those with disabilities) is prohibited. Exceptions exist. The policy is slated to end on November 26. UPDATE: From 27 November 2020, exceptions are slightly specified. In addition to utilizing health services, getting tested for COVID-19 in the context of screening programmes may also be exempted from lockdown restrictions. It is now made explicit that staying outside for recovering purposes is only allowed if alone, with those from the same household or those according to § 1, section 1, no. 3, lit. a) of the source document, that is, here, exceptions are extended. When allowedly contacting other persons, it is now to be ensured that, on the one end, persons from one outside household at most and, on the other hand, only one person, are involved hereby at the same time. Lockdown restrictions are extended to December 6. UPDATE: From 27 November 2020, exceptions are slightly specified. In addition to utilizing health services, getting tested for COVID-19 in the context of screening programmes may also be exempted from lockdown restrictions. It is now made explicit that staying outside for recovering purposes is only allowed if alone, with those from the same household or those according to § 1, section 1, no. 3, lit. a) of the source document, that is, here, exceptions are extended. Lockdown restrictions are extended to December 6.

description:
Austria, Lower Austria, April 14, 2021.
Extended COVID-19 lockdown in Lower Austria until May 2, 2021, as opposed to April 18, 2021 (intended end date).
20:00-06:00 curfew remains in effect, during which residents may only leave their homes for limited essential purposes. 
Outside of curfew hours, up to four adults from a maximum of two different households are permitted to meet socially. 
Individuals must keep at least 2 meters (6 feet) away from members of other households.

description:
On March 15, 2020, the Austrian government adopted the COVID-19 Act and several regulations that tighten restrictions already put in place to prevent or contain the spread of the novel coronavirus in Austria and to make money available to deal with the economic fallout from the pandemic. The measures include the following:

-The establishment of a crisis management fund
-Measures to support employers and employees affected by COVID-19
-Closures of or restrictions on entering certain business premises
-The reintroduction of border controls and travel restrictions from certain countries to Austria
-Prohibition on gathering in public places

description:
Original policy: Health Minister Rudolf Anschober (Greens) presented a preview of the planned “Corona-Ampel,” the coronavirus “traffic-light” warning systems for Austrian regions that should be tested in August and fully launched in September.

Update: In Austria, CoV-Ampel (corona traffic light system) was officially launched on September 4. restrictions will be valid starting from September 11.
The system consists of four colors, from green (low risk) to red (very high risk).
When the traffic light is yellow:
-Masks must be worn inside stores, restaurants, schools, and at events.
-Events with reserved seating arrangements will be limited to 2,500 people.
-Events without reserved seats will be limited to 100 people.
-To host events with 500 or more people, one must first submit a request at the respective district office.
-Outdoor events with reserved seats are limited to 5000 people. Without reserved seats, outdoor events are limited to 100 attendees. When seated, guests are not required to wear a mask.
-When the light is green, hygiene guidelines will still be enforced.

description: Announced on September 3, 2020, the Austrian Government introduces a new 'traffic light' system, with different measures affecting different areas of the country, starting on September 4, 2020. Color green means low risk. There are single cases and isolated clusters. Color yellow means medium risk. There is a moderate number of cases that can be primarily assigned to clusters. Color orange means high risk. There is an accumulation of cases that can no longer be predominantly assigned to clusters. Color red means a very high risk. There are uncontrolled outbreaks and widespread spread.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description:
Effective December 17th, 2021, Austria introduced a so-called "Holiday Ninja Pass" for young people of school age from Austria and abroad who have not been (fully) vaccinated or do not have proof of past infection to use alternative 2-G proof in Austria. 
The Ninja Pass, by means of docmenting a series of test results, is equivalent to 2-G proof for 7 days for teenagers, from age 12 and born on or after 1 September 2006, if 
a. there is proof of a valid negative test result from day 1 to day 5,
b. at least 2 of the tests taken are molecular biological tests for SARS-CoV-2 (PCR tests) and, 
c. all official test certificates are recorded in the Holiday Ninja Pass in analogue or digital form.
The Holiday Ninja Pass regulations are analogous to those of the Corona Test Pass (Ninja Pass) at Austrian schools, according to which the period of validity for antigen tests is 48 hours and for PCR tests 72 hours, and is valid for the winter season 2021/22.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
type_text: The policy in question provides alternative means for non-fully vaccinated and recovered school-aged children in Austria to achieve 2-G status.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: People of a certain age (please note age range in the text entry)

description: Effective February 1st, 2022, Austria becomes the first country to enforce a mandatory COVID-19 vaccine mandate for residents aged 18 or older, with exemptions for pregnant women and people who cannot receive the vaccine on medical grounds. The law takes effect on February 1 but police checks won't be carried out until March 15. Unvaccinated people then face a penalty of around €600 and up to €3,600. In total, those not complying with the mandate can be fined up to four times a year. A fine will be dropped if the recipient gets vaccinated within two weeks of receiving the penalty notice.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type_text: This policy enforces a national COVID-19 vaccination mandate.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
The Austrian Foreign Ministry issued a travel warning for the countries of the Western Balkans due to rising coronavirus cases in the region.
Concretely, the ministry advises not to travel to Serbia, Montenegro, Bosnia & Herzegovina, North Macedonia, Albania and Kosovo.
Travelers coming from these countries to Austria need to self-quarantine for 14 days or show a negative COVID-19 test result.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Ministry/Department of Justice

description:
Travelers entering Austria from any of the following countries (see below) need to self-quarantine for 14 days at home or otherwise show a negative COVID-19 test result.

People living in Austria are advised not to travel currently to the following countries (in parentheses, number of new coronavirus infections in the last 14 days per 100,000 inhabitants): Bosnia & Herzegovina (6.2) Montenegro (8.4) Serbia (5.2) Montenegro (8.5) North Macedonia (9.3) Albania (3.4) Bulgaria (2.8) Romania (2.6) Moldova (8.5) Ukraine (2.7) Turkey (2.1)
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs

description:
The federal states of Lower Austria and Upper Austria shortened the quarantine period for COVID-19 suspected cases to 10 days from previously 14 days.
The change follows a recommendation from the Ministry of Health.
The quarantine can only be ended if there are still no symptoms after 10 days; for people who tested positive for the coronavirus in the past or who show symptoms, a negative test result is obligatory.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
When arriving in Austria from the below-listed countries, you do not need to go into quarantine or present a negative PCR test.

Australia, Belgium (except the areas of Brussels and Wallonia), Bulgaria (except the regions Blagoevgrad, Burgas, Dobrich, Gabrovo, Jambol, Kardzhali, Montana, Plovdiv, Rasgrad, Shumen, Sliven, Smoljan, Sofia, Stara Zagora, Targovishte, Varna), Canada, Cyprus, Croatia (the regions Brod-Posavina, Istria, Koprivnica-Križevci, Osijek-Baranja, Šibenik-Knin, Varaždin, and Zadar only), Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France (except Île-de-France (Paris), Provence-Alpes-Cote d’Azur), Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Japan, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Monaco, Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Poland, Portugal (except Lisbon and Norte), San Marino, Slovakia, Slovenia, South Korea, the Canary Islands in Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, United Kingdom (except North East, East Midlands, Yorkshire and the Humber), Uruguay, Vatican City.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Military,Police

description:
Individuals coming from the countries below are required to present a negative  PCR test on arrival (within 48 hours) or go into ten day mandatory quarantine.

The following are considered high-risk areas by the Austrian government: Andorra, Albania, Argentina, Bahrain, Bangladesh, Belarus, the areas of Brussels and Wallonia in Belgium, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Brazil, Bulgaria (the regions Blagoevgrad, Burgas, Dobrich, Gabrovo, Jambol, Kardzhali, Montana, Plovdiv, Rasgrad, Shumen, Sliven, Smoljan, Sofia, Stara Zagora, Targovishte, Varna only), Chile, Costa Rica, Croatia (except Brod-Posavina, Istria, Koprivnica-Križevci, Osijek-Baranja, Šibenik-Knin, Varaždin, and Zadar), Czech Republic, Ecuador, Egypt, Île-de-France (Paris) and Provence-Alpes-Cote d’Azur in France, India, Indonesia, Iran, Israel, Kosovo, Kuwait, Maldives, Mexico, Moldavia, Montenegro, Nigeria, North Macedonia, Pakistan, Peoples Republic of China – Province Hubei, Peru, Philippines, Lisbon and Norte in Portugal, Romania, Russian Federation, Senegal, Serbia, South Africa, mainland Spain and the Balearic Islands, Turkey, the areas of the North East, the East Midlands, Yorkshire and the Humber in the United Kingdom, Ukraine and USA.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
From 19th of December, the Federal Ministry of Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that persons entering the country from a defined risk area are required to quarantine for 10 days upon arrival. After 5 days of quarantine at the earliest, you may take a PCR or antigen COVID test to shorten the quarantine. Moreover, it is possible to end the quarantine if the person decides to leave the country.

The only countries considered as non-risk areas are Australia, Finland, Ireland, Iceland, Japan, New Zealand, Norway, South Korea, Uruguay, and the Vatican, which are exempted from the policy.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:

description: On January 6, 2021, the Austrian government announced that travelers arriving from a designated risk area will be required to self-isolate for 10 days. However, those in quarantine can end after five days if the traveler presents a negative COVID-19 polymerase chain reaction PCR test result. All countries will be considered risk areas, with the exception of Australia, Finland, Iceland, Ireland, Japan, New Zealand, Norway, South Korea, Uruguay, and Vatican City.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On February 22, 2021, the Austrian government announced that travelers from risk areas must self-isolate for 10 days on arrival, though they can end self isolation early by taking a COVID-19 test after five days. All countries are considered risk areas with the exception of Australia, Finland, Greece, Iceland, New Zealand, Norway, Singapore, South Korea, and the Vatican City.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On June 25, 2021, Austria announced that, starting from July 1st, 2021, all people who have been in and entering from one of the states or region that does not belong to that on the low epidemiological risk nor the virus variant list must provide a “proof of low epidemiological risk" and be quarantined for 10 days once they entered. The quarantine will be over if the individual is tested negative on the fifth day. Citizens and individual seeking medical help, people who are stopping for connecting flights, travelling to another destination, crew of repatriation trips, essential transportation, people entering for animal care/agriculture/forestry purposes, occupants of emergency vehicles, professional transfer trip, people entering certain communities and those that are of interest of Austria are exempted from the policy. The policy is set to end on August 31, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On June 25, Austria announced that, starting from July 1, 2021, , travellers who had been in any of the virus-variant areas and states in the past 10 days are prohibited from entering Austria. The policy, however, does allow exemptions under certain circumstances. Those that are exempted and are permitted to enter Austria (Austrian citizens; EU/EEA citizens; Swizz citizens; residents of EU/EEA states or residents of Andorra, Monaco, San Marino, the Vatican or Switzerland; individuals with residence permits, documentations, or title; diplomatic staff; international organisation staff; employees of certain corporations; students; school staff; professionals; humanitarian responders; individuals with court obligation; individuals attending important family events or with family emergency.) must go through a 10 day quarantine upon entering the country. The quarantine can be terminated if the individual tested negative on the fifth day. Certain individuals are exempted from this quarantine policy. The policy is set to end on August 31, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On July 5, 2021, Austria added Russia to the list of "virus variants" countries and "“Armenia” , “Azerbaijan” , “Bosnia and Herzegovina” , “Brunei” , “Jordan” , “Canada” , “Qatar”, “Kosovo” , “Moldova” and “Montenegro”" are added to the list of countries that are considered "low epidemiological risk". Restrictions applies to these countries according to their categories. The change comes into effect on July 8, 2021. On June 25, 2021, Austria announced that, starting from July 1st, 2021, all people who have been in and entering from one of the states or region that does not belong to that on the low epidemiological risk nor the virus variant list must provide a “proof of low epidemiological risk" and be quarantined for 10 days once they entered. The quarantine will be over if the individual is tested negative on the fifth day.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On July 5, 2021, Austria announced that Russia is added to the list of countries considered "virus-variant" and the same restrictions would apply to it. The change in policy is in effect on July 8, 2021. On June 25, Austria announced that, starting from July 1, 2021,  travellers who had been in any of the virus-variant areas and states in the past 10 days are prohibited from entering Austria. The policy, however, does allow exemptions under certain circumstances. Those that are exempted and are permitted to enter Austria (Austrian citizens; EU/EEA citizens; Swizz citizens; residents of EU/EEA states or residents of Andorra, Monaco, San Marino, the Vatican or Switzerland; individuals with residence permits, documentations, or title; diplomatic staff; international organisation staff; employees of certain corporations; students; school staff; professionals; humanitarian responders; individuals with court obligation; individuals attending important family events or with family emergency.) must go through a 10 day quarantine upon entering the country. The quarantine can be terminated if the individual tested negative on the fifth day. Certain individuals are exempted from this quarantine policy. The policy is set to end on August 31, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On June 25, 2021, Austria announced that, starting from July 1st, 2021, all people who have been in and entering from one of the states or region that does not belong to that on the low epidemiological risk nor the virus variant list must provide a “proof of low epidemiological risk" and be quarantined for 10 days once they entered. The quarantine will be over if the individual is tested negative on the fifth day. Citizens and individual seeking medical help, people who are stopping for connecting flights, travelling to another destination, crew of repatriation trips, essential transportation, people entering for animal care/agriculture/forestry purposes, occupants of emergency vehicles, professional transfer trip, people entering certain communities and those that are of interest of Austria are exempted from the policy. The policy is set to end on August 31, 2021. UPDATE: On July 5, 2021, Austria added Russia to the list of "virus variants" countries and "“Armenia” , “Azerbaijan” , “Bosnia and Herzegovina” , “Brunei” , “Jordan” , “Canada” , “Qatar”, “Kosovo” , “Moldova” and “Montenegro”" are added to the list of countries that are considered "low epidemiological risk". Restrictions applies to these countries according to their categories. The change comes into effect on July 8, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On June 25, 2021, Austria announced that, starting from July 1, 2021, people who had been into one of the "virus variant" countries would be prohibited to enter Austria. Certain exceptions do apply to the policy, and those who were granted an entry must go through 10 days of quarantine. The quarantine can be ended if the individual tested negative on the fifth day. On August 13, 2021, ""Botswana" , "India" , "Nepal" , "Russia" , "Zambia" , "South Africa" ​​and "United Kingdom"" are removed from the list of countries that are considered high risk. This change would be in effect on August 15, 2021 and is set to end on September 30, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On June 25, 2021, Austria announced that, starting from July 1st, 2021, all people who have been in and entering from one of the states or region that does not belong to that on the low epidemiological risk nor the virus variant list must provide a “proof of low epidemiological risk" and be quarantined for 10 days once they entered. The quarantine will be over if the individual is tested negative on the fifth day.  On July 5, 2021, Austria added Russia to the list of "virus variants" countries and "“Armenia” , “Azerbaijan” , “Bosnia and Herzegovina” , “Brunei” , “Jordan” , “Canada” , “Qatar”, “Kosovo” , “Moldova” and “Montenegro”" are added to the list of countries that are considered "low epidemiological risk". Restrictions applies to these countries according to their categories. The change comes into effect on July 8, 2021. The policy is set to end on August 31, 2021. UPDATE: On August 13, 2021, Austria announced that the effect of the entry policy regarding covid-19 would be extended to September 30, 2021 when it was set to end on August 31, 2021 originally.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Quarantine outside the home or government facility (i.e. quarantine in a hotel)

description:
On October 27, 2021, Austria added ""Bosnia and Herzegovina" and "Moldova" are deleted and the words "Kuwait" and "Rwanda""
 to the list of countries that are considered low epidemiological risk. The change will take effect on November 1, 2021 and is set to end on December 31, 2021. On June 25, 2021, Austria announced that, starting from July 1st, 2021, all people who have been in and entering from one of the states or region that does not belong to that on the low epidemiological risk nor the virus variant list must provide a “proof of low epidemiological risk" and be quarantined for 10 days once they entered. The quarantine will be over if the individual is tested negative on the fifth day.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
