description: On September 10, 2021, Austria announced that ""Albania" , "Armenia" , "Azerbaijan" , "Brunei" , "Israel" , "Japan" , "Kosovo" , "Montenegro" , "North Macedonia" , "Serbia" , "Thailand"" from the list of countries that are considered low epidemiological risk and added United States and Uruguay onto the list. Austria removed ""Eswatini" , "Lesotho" , "Malawi" , "Mozambique" , "Namibia" , "Zimbabwe" and "Uruguay"" from the list of countries that are considered high risk (virus-variant). ""Chile" , "Costa Rica ". ' and 'Suriname'" are added onto the list. People who had been in one of these countries in the past 10 days now follows the Austrian protocols for all people who have been in and entering from one of the states or region that does not belong to that on the low epidemiological risk nor the virus variant list must provide a “proof of low epidemiological risk" and be quarantined for 10 days once they entered. The quarantine will be over if the individual is tested negative on the fifth day. This policy is set to end on October 31, 2021. UPDATE: On October 27, 2021, Austria removed all countries from its list of countries that are considered "high risk". The change would be in effect on November 1, 2021. This version of the policy is terminated.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On June 25, 2021, Austria announced that, starting from July 1, 2021, people who had been into one of the "virus variant" countries would be prohibited to enter Austria. Certain exceptions do apply to the policy, and those who were granted an entry must go through 10 days of quarantine. The quarantine can be ended if the individual tested negative on the fifth day. On August 13, 2021, ""Botswana" , "India" , "Nepal" , "Russia" , "Zambia" , "South Africa" ​​and "United Kingdom"" are removed from the list of countries that are considered high risk. On September 10, 2021, Austria removed ""Eswatini" , "Lesotho" , "Malawi" , "Mozambique" , "Namibia" , "Zimbabwe" and "Uruguay"" from the list of countries that are considered high risk (virus-variant). ""Chile" , "Costa Rica ". ' and 'Suriname'" are added onto the list. The change in policy is in effect on September 15, 2021. The policy is set to end on October 31. UPDATE: On October 27, 2021, Austria removed all countries from its list of countries to be considered "high-risk". The change will be in effect on November 1, 2021 and is expected to last until December 31, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On October 27, 2021, Austria added ""Bosnia and Herzegovina" and "Moldova" are deleted and the words "Kuwait" and "Rwanda""
 to the list of countries that are considered low epidemiological risk. The change will take effect on November 1, 2021 and is set to end on December 31, 2021. On June 25, 2021, Austria announced that, starting from July 1st, 2021, all people who have been in and entering from one of the states or region that does not belong to that on the low epidemiological risk nor the virus variant list must provide a “proof of low epidemiological risk" and be quarantined for 10 days once they entered. The quarantine will be over if the individual is tested negative on the fifth day. UPDATE: On November 26, 2021, Austria added ""Botswana" , "Eswatini" , "Lesotho" , "Mozambique" , ​​"Namibia" , "Zimbabwe" and "South Africa"" to the list of countries that are considered virus-variant areas. The changes will come in effect on November 27, 2021. This version of the policy is terminated.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Quarantine outside the home or government facility (i.e. quarantine in a hotel)

description: On December 23, 2021, Austria added "United Kingdom," "Norway," "Netherlands," and "Denmark" onto the list of countries that are considered "virus-variant". People who had been in one of these countries in the past 10 days are forbidden from entering Austria. Certain exceptions to the policy apply. Those who were permitted to enter must be quarantined for 10 days once they entered. The quarantine will be over if the individual is tested negative on the fifth day.The change will be in effect on December 25, 2021 and is set to end on January 31, 2022.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On 30 December 2021, the committee of the Austrian National Council,  has extended the quarantine measure until January 10th, 2022. Austria’s stay-at-home quarantine for unvaccinated people has been extended until January 10th, although an exception for New Year's eve has been included. The decision, which was widely expected, means those who are not vaccinated or who have not recently recovered from the virus will need to continue to comply with the stay-at-home order
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: People who are not vaccinated against COVID-19

description: Starting from 1 January 2022 People who have been in contact with someone who tests positive for Omicron are considered Category 1 (K1) contacts. This means that even vaccinated people who have been in contact with a person infected with Omicron need to self-isolate for ten days, although they can take a PCR test to end the quarantine early after &ve days if they test negative.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: Since January 24, 2022 guests from all countries Non-vaccinated or recovered persons (i.e. without valid 2-G proof) are allowed to enter Austria with a registration obligation and mandatory quarantine for 10 days, exempt testing only from the 5th day. The entry regulation is provisionally valid until February 28, 2022.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From March 21st, 2022, Austria announced that close contacts of a positive case will no longer have to quarantine completely and will be able to go to work or shopping while wearing a mask, but not to restaurants or events.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: In Austria, COVID-positive people need to stay at home and go through quarantine for 10 days. The quarantine can be ended automatically after five days if a PCR test comes back negative or with a CT value above 30 if you don’t have any symptoms for at least 48h ( 21 March 2022).
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
In Austria, COVID-positive people need to stay at home and go through quarantine for 10 days. The quarantine can be ended automatically after five days if a PCR test comes back negative or with a CT value above 30 if you don’t have any symptoms for at least 48h ( 21 March 2022).
 UPDATE: On 26 July 2022, Austria announced that people who test positive for Covid-19 will no longer be required to self-isolate in Austria.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 15, 2022 Ministry of Health announced New Covid Rules in Vienna. There is no abbreviated quarantine in Vienna. The quarantine is uniformly for 10 days and ends automatically if one is symptom-free 48 hours before expiration. Free testing is possible after 5 days. In case of a free test, the quarantine ends if the CT value is above 30 or the test is negative.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: Effective August 1st, those who test positive for COVID-19 but do not show any symptoms will no longer have to quarantine themselves. However, they will still be required to wear masks if they leave their home unless they are outside or can keep a distance of at least two meters (six feet) from others. They are also not allowed to enter places catering to especially vulnerable people such as hospitals nursing homes or facilities for the disabled. Mandatory reporting of COVID-19 infections to local health authorities remains in place.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 14, 2020, Austria's Landeck district authority announced that all inhabitants and residents of the region are prohibited from using routes that "serve the purpose of handling the ski bus service, as well as using cable cars." Routes that are essential for the function of local public transport are permitted and not affected by this regulation. Violation of this policy can lead to four weeks of jail time or a fine of 1450 euros. The policy is in effect on March 14, 2020, and is set to end on April 13, 2020.

description: On March 15, 2020, Austria declared curfew for hospitality business. Business within this category must close by 3 p.m. everyday and may open at 5 a.m.. There are exceptions to this policty ("hospitals and sanatoriums; nursing homes and retirement homes; Facilities for the care and accommodation of children and young people, including schools and kindergartens; companies if they may only be used by company employees."). The policy will start on the day it is announced and end on March 16, 2020.

description: In Austria, from March 16, 2020, all ski lifts in Carinthia are closed, announced March 12 by the regional government. This policy effectively extends over the whole rest of the 2020 skiing season. After that, it automatically becomes obsolete, as it only relates to skiing in winter 2020. The end date is thus implied, though not specified. UPDATE: It was announced that the skiing season would be terminated early for 2020. No explicit end date of the policy was mentioned, but it was implied that there would be no more skiing possible in Carinthia for the rest of the 2020 winter, with the policy effectively becoming obsolete after that.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description: In Austria, from March 16, 2020, all ski lifts in Styria are closed, announced March 12 by the regional government. UPDATE: There was no clear end date announced for the policy. However, it was implicitly clear that the policy would become obsolete after the winter, as it related only to the skiing season, which was terminated early for the year.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description: In Austria, from March 16, 2020, all ski lifts in Tyrol are closed, announced March 12 by the regional governments. UPDATE: This policy effectively extends over the whole rest of the 2020 skiing season. After that, it automatically becomes obsolete, as it only relates to skiing in winter 2020. The end date is thus implied, though not specified. UPDATE: It was announced that the skiing season would be terminated early for 2020. No explicit end date of the policy was mentioned, but it was implied that there would be no more skiing possible in Tyrol for the rest of the 2020 winter, with the policy effectively becoming obsolete after that.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description: On March 17, 2020, Landeck announced that "Driving on the entire L 348 Spisser Straße from the intersection with the B 180 Reschenstraße to the border crossing point/customs office Spiss is prohibited for all vehicle traffic." The access to Spiss is not prohibited by this policy. The policy is in effect on March 17, 2020 and is expected to end on March 28, 2020. Violation to the policy can result in "a fine of up to EUR 1,450.00, in the event of irrecoverability with imprisonment of up to four weeks."

The policy is in effect on March 17, 2020 and is expected to end on March 28, 2020. description: On March 14, 2020, Austria's town Kufstein in the state of Tyrol announced that entries to all hospitality businesses for entertainment and performing purposes are prohibited. No indoor or outdoor operation of such a type of business is allowed. This policy affects "all hospitality business for tourism purposes," with the exception of "the provision of food for the basic needs of the population." Violation of this policy can lead to up to four weeks of jail time or a fine of 1450 euros. The policy is in effect at the end of March 16, 2020, and is set to end on April 13, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: Non-Essential Businesses
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description:
From March 17, 2020, Austria announced the closing of restaurants and bars.

From April 21, 2020, Austria announced that:
From May 1: all shops and stores can reopen, including hair & beauty salons;
From May 15: restaurants, bars and other businesses in the hospitality industry can reopen (until 23:00 in the night), for staff it’s mandatory to wear mask
 UPDATE: The original policy had restaurant and bars close from 3PM on; later - policy closed restaurants and bars entirely. 

The new policy indicates that from:
May 1: all shops and stores can reopen, including hair & beauty salons;
May 15: restaurants, bars and other businesses in the hospitality industry can reopen (until 23:00 in the night), for staff it’s mandatory to wear mask

 UPDATE: The original policy had restaurant and bars close from 3PM on; later - policy closed restaurants and bars entirely. 

The new policy indicates that from:
May 1: all shops and stores can reopen, including hair & beauty salons;
May 15: restaurants, bars and other businesses in the hospitality industry can reopen (until 23:00 in the night), for staff it’s mandatory to wear mask
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: On March 21, 2020, the city of Innsbruck in Austria announced the closure of 18 locations (footpaths and parking lots) in the city to prevent the spread of the virus. Both entering and driving in such places are forbidden, with the exception of entry or driving with the purpose of emergency or public services. Failure to comply can result in a fine up to 3600 euros or up to four weeks in jail. The policy is effective at the end of March 21, 2020.

description: From 16 March 2020, the Federal Ministry for Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering the costumer areas of trading, service, leisure and sports facilities for the purpose of purchasing goods or making use of services as well as leisure and sports facilities is prohibited. Exceptions exist. The policy is slated to end on March 22. UPDATE: From 23 March 2020, exceptions for drug stores and markets, the selling of medical products, sanitary articles, therapeutic and medical aids, the selling of fodder, the selling and maintaining of safety and emergency products as well as agriculture trade are valid from 7:40 am to 7 pm at the longest on workdays. Exceptions for food trade and agricultural direct marketers (outside of selling points of food producers) are valid from 7:40 am to 7 pm at the longest on workdays. UPDATE: From 23 March 2020, exceptions for drug stores and markets, the selling of medical products, sanitary articles, therapeutic and medical aids, the selling of fodder, the selling and maintaining of safety and emergency products as well as agriculture trade are valid from 7:40 am to 7 pm at the longest on workdays. Exceptions for food trade and agricultural direct marketers (outside of selling points of food producers) are valid from 7:40 am to 7 pm at the longest on workdays.

description:
On March 27, 2020, Tyrol announced that "access to and from the Paznaun Valley and to and from St. Anton am Arlberg
are banned." This policy has does not apply to trips of blue-light organizations, trip carrying supplies, public services and infrastructure trips, trips with the purpose of health care, trip to care "for the elderly and the sick," or "group repatriations and individual trips of foreign staff of tourism companies and foreign holiday guests that have been approved in advance by the authority in individual cases and are escorted by the public security service, as part of the controlled departure" with official signatures. Offense to this policy may result in fine up to 3600 euros or, if the fine cannot be paid, up to four weeks' imprisonment. The policy come into effect on the end of March 27, 2020 and is set to end on April 13, 2020.

description: In Austria, from March 16, 2020, all ski lifts in Salzburg are closed, announced March 12 by the regional governments. The skiing season is terminated early for the year. UPDATE: All lifts and cableways are to stay closed until  April 30th. UPDATE: Initially, no clear end date for the closing of lifts was specified, except that the skiing season was terminated early for the year. On April 10th, Salzburg announced that all lifts were to stay closed until April 30th.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: From 17 March 2020, the Federal Ministry for Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering the premises of all modes of operation in the catering industry is prohibited. Exceptions exist. The policy is slated to end on March 22. UPDATE: From 14 April 2020, catering industry restrictions are extended to April 30. UPDATE: From 14 April 2020, catering industry restrictions are extended to April 30.

update_level_var: [compliance] of policy relaxing ; timing of policy strengthening
description: From 16 March 2020, the Federal Ministry for Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering the costumer areas of trading, service, leisure and sports facilities for the purpose of purchasing goods or making use of services as well as leisure and sports facilities is prohibited. Exceptions exist. The policy is slated to end on March 22. UPDATE: From 14 April 2020, exceptions are extended and now also include filling stations and affiliated car washes, car and bicycle service stations, building material, iron, timber and precious metals trades as well as building and garten centres and pawn offices. Exceptions for building material, iron, timber and precious metals trades as well as building and garten centres, and pawn offices are valid from 07:40 am to 7 pm at the longest on workdays. Additionally, if inside costumer areas have a size of less than 400 m², other trade facilities (according to § 2, section 4 of the source document) may be exempted as well (in line with the provisions stated in § 2, section 4 of the source document). Operators of these other trade facilities are required to ensure that the number of costumers in costumer areas is regulated such that for 20 m² of selling space only 1 customer may be allowed to be located there, for selling spaces of less than 20 m² no more than 1 costumer is allowed to be located there. Exceptions may now only be granted if employees in situations of costumer contact and costumers from 6 (years of age) upwards wear a face mask (does not apply to health and care services where alternative provisions and recommendations are in place separately) and minimum distance (1m) measures are followed (does not apply to health and care services). Restrictions for trading, service, leisure and sports facilities are extended to April 30. UPDATE: From 14 April 2020, exceptions are extended and now also include filling stations and affiliated car washes, car and bicycle service stations, building material, iron, timber and precious metals trades as well as building and garten centres and pawn offices. Exceptions for building material, iron, timber and precious metals trades as well as building and garten centres, and pawn offices are valid from 07:40 am to 7 pm at the longest on workdays. Additionally, if inside costumer areas have a size of less than 400 m², other trade facilities (according to § 2, section 4 of the source document) may be exempted as well (in line with the provisions stated in § 2, section 4 of the source document). Operators of these other trade facilities are required to ensure that the number of costumers in costumer areas is regulated such that for 20 m² of selling space only 1 customer may be allowed to be located there, for selling spaces of less than 20 m² no more than 1 costumer is allowed to be located there. Exceptions may now only be granted if employees in situations of costumer contact and costumers from 6 (years of age) upwards wear a face mask (does not apply to health and care services where alternative provisions and recommendations are in place separately) and minimum distance (1m) measures are followed (does not apply to health and care services). Restrictions for trading, service, leisure and sports facilities are extended to April 30.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On April 23, 2020, Austria announced that the transportation restriction against trucks and trailers will be lifted temporarily due to the pandemic. This means that they are allow to be on the roads on Saturdays, Sundays, and public holidays all day. They can also carry more than 3.5 tons of cargo. This policy is in effect on April 24, 2020 and is set to end on May 17, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: Essential Businesses
institution_status: This type of business ("Transportation (land; water and air)") is allowed to open with no conditions attached
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

update_level_var: [compliance] of policy relaxing ; timing of policy strengthening
description: From 17 March 2020, the Federal Ministry for Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering the premises of all modes of operation in the catering industry is prohibited. Exceptions exist. The policy is slated to end on March 22. UPDATE: From 1 May 2020, it is explicitly stated that minimum distance measures are to be followed towards those not from the same household if exceptions are granted. For takeouts of pre-ordered meals, face covering is required additionally. Exceptions may now also be granted to instances of occupational necessity. Catering industry restrictions are extended to June 30. UPDATE: From 1 May 2020, it is explicitly stated that minimum distance measures are to be followed towards those not from the same household if exceptions are granted. For takeouts of pre-ordered meals, face covering is required additionally. Exceptions may now also be granted to instances of occupational necessity. Catering industry restrictions are extended to June 30.

description: From 16 March 2020, the Federal Ministry for Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering the costumer areas of trading, service, leisure and sports facilities for the purpose of purchasing goods or making use of services as well as leisure and sports facilities is prohibited. Exceptions exist. The policy is slated to end on March 22. UPDATE: From 1 May 2020, restrictions for trading and service facilities are lifted. Entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort is now allowed if the conditions according to § 2, sections 1 to 5 of the source document are met. Entering sports ground for carrying out sports activities and leisure facilities (with the exception of within private living space and according to § 9, section 2 of the source document) for visitors remains to be prohibited. UPDATE: From 1 May 2020, restrictions for trading and service facilities are lifted. Entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort is now allowed if the conditions according to § 2, sections 1 to 5 of the source document are met. Entering sports ground for carrying out sports activities and leisure facilities (with the exception of within private living space and according to § 9, section 2 of the source document) for visitors remains to be prohibited.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 1 May 2020, entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets) is allowed if social distancing, face covering or other infection protection measures are followed (see [type_business_var]). Entering sports grounds for carrying out sports activities is, with exceptions, prohibited. Entering leisure facilities for entertaining, amusing or recreational purposes is, with exceptions, prohibited for visitors. The policy is slated to end on June 30. UPDATE: From 15 May 2020, entering sports grounds is now generally prohibited. Exceptions are revised accordingly. Entering the visitor areas of animal parks and zoos is now allowed if conditions according to § 2, section 1, numbers 1 to 5 (§ 1, section 1 for outdoor visitor areas) of the source document are met. In the context of leisure facility restrictions, entering the premises of cruise vessels is now prohibited for those of occasional character ("im Gelegenheitsverkehr"). For dance schools, dancing couples may be exempted if from the same household and each couple is provided a dance floor of 10 m² at the least, private lessons are generally allowed. Drive-in cinemas (for multi-lane motor vehicles) may now also be exempted from restrictions. UPDATE: From 15 May 2020, entering sports grounds is now generally prohibited. Exceptions are revised accordingly. Entering the visitor areas of animal parks and zoos is now allowed if conditions according to § 2, section 1, numbers 1 to 5 (§ 1, section 1 for outdoor visitor areas) of the source document are met. In the context of leisure facility restrictions, entering the premises of cruise vessels is now prohibited for those of occasional character ("im Gelegenheitsverkehr"). For dance schools, dancing couples may be exempted if from the same household and each couple is provided a dance floor of 10 m² at the least, private lessons are generally allowed. Drive-in cinemas (for multi-lane motor vehicles) may now also be exempted from restrictions.

description: From 17 March 2020, the Federal Ministry for Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering the premises of all modes of operation in the catering industry is prohibited. Exceptions exist. The policy is slated to end on March 22. UPDATE: From 15 May 2020, catering industry restrictions are lifted. Entering the premises of all modes of operation in the catering industry is now allowed if the provisions stated in § 6, sections 2 to 10 of the source document are followed. This also applies to gastronomical facilities for the provision of meals and drinks within accommodation providers. Chosen facilities are exempted from the obligation to follow these rules. UPDATE: From 15 May 2020, catering industry restrictions are lifted. Entering the premises of all modes of operation in the catering industry is now allowed if the provisions stated in § 6, sections 2 to 10 of the source document are followed. This also applies to gastronomical facilities for the provision of meals and drinks within accommodation providers. Chosen facilities are exempted from the obligation to follow these rules.

description: From May 29th, hotels and other accomodation facilities can reopen in Austria. Nevertheless, certain control measures have to be insured: - Ensure a minimum distance of 1 meter (Place information by means of displays, signs, stands, floor markings or other aids in the entrance areas and at the reception of the accommodation company and etc).- Design the catering area (Observe guidelines for catering establishments for general information)- Adapt additional offers (fitness areas and wellness areas, according to their requirements)- Place recommendations for behavior that are clearly visible to the guest

description: From 15 May 2020, the Federal Ministry for Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering the premises of all modes of operation in the catering industry is allowed if certain conditions are met (see [type_business_var]). For some facilities, following these rules is not explicitly mandatory (see exceptions section). The policy is slated to end on June 30. UPDATE: From 29 May 2020, the joint admission of multiple interrelated visitor groups may be allowed if minimum distance measures are followed or appropriate safeguards for social distancing are installed. Operators and employees may forego wearing a face mask in situations of customer contact if appropriate safeguards for social distancing are available. Catering industry provisions are extended to August 31. description: In Austria, the original policy limited the working time and number of people of restaurants and bars, as well as mandatory masks wearing requirements for customers and personnel existed (from May 15th). Starting on June 15th, people will be able to sit on a restaurant table with more than 4 people (also from different households), masks will be mandatory only for personnel and restaurants and bars can stay opened until 1:00 am in the morning (before until 23:00).

description: From 30 May 2020, entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets) is allowed if social distancing, face covering or other infection protection measures are followed (see [type_business_var]). Entering sports grounds is allowed if conditions according to § 2, section 1, numbers 1 to 3 and § 8, sections 2 to 5 (§ 1, section 1 and § 8, sections 2 to 5 for outdoor sports grounds) of the source document are met. Entering the visitor areas of leisure facilities is now allowed if the conditions according to § 2, section 1, numbers 1 to 3 (§ 1, section 1 for outdoor visitor areas) of the source document are met. Entering the premises of the sex trade industry remains to be prohibited. The policy is slated to end on June 30. UPDATE: From 15 June 2020, when entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets), now only social distancing measures are to be followed (also applies to sports grounds and leisure facilities). Face covering is still mandatory for costumers when entering pharmacies and for their operators and employees whenever there is costumer contact (here, provisions with respect to costumers for being exempted from face covering measures are no longer valid). When carrying out sports activities at sports grounds, keeping a minimum distance of 2 metres now generally applies. Provisions for outdoor visitor areas of leisure facilities are no longer valid. UPDATE: From 15 June 2020, when entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets), now only social distancing measures are to be followed (also applies to sports grounds and leisure facilities). Face covering is still mandatory for costumers when entering pharmacies and for their operators and employees whenever there is costumer contact (here, provisions with respect to costumers for being exempted from face covering measures are no longer valid). When carrying out sports activities at sports grounds, keeping a minimum distance of 2 metres now generally applies. Provisions for outdoor visitor areas of leisure facilities are no longer valid.

description: From 29 May 2020, the Federal Ministry for Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering the premises of all modes of operation in the catering industry is allowed if certain conditions are met (see [type_business_var]). Conditions have changed when compared to the regulatory situation of May 15. For some facilities, following these rules is not explicitly mandatory (see exceptions section). The policy is slated to end on August 31. UPDATE: From 15 June 2020, opening hours for the admission of customers are extended and now go from 6 am to 1 am the next day. The admission of visitor groups is no longer attached to conditions. Wearing a face mask in confined spaces is no longer mandatory. The takeaway of meals and drinks is no longer attached to conditions. UPDATE: From 15 June 2020, opening hours for the admission of customers are extended and now go from 6 am to 1 am the next day. The admission of visitor groups is no longer attached to conditions. Wearing a face mask in confined spaces is no longer mandatory. The takeaway of meals and drinks is no longer attached to conditions.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions

description: In Austria, the original policy limited the working time and number of people of restaurants and bars, as well as mandatory masks wearing requirements for customers and personnel existed (from May 15th). Starting on June 15th, people will be able to sit on a restaurant table with more than 4 people (also from different households), masks will be mandatory only for personnel and restaurants and bars can stay opened until 1:00 am in the morning (before until 23:00). UPDATE: In Austria, the original policy limited the working time and number of people of restaurants and bars, as well as mandatory masks wearing requirements for customers and personnel existed (from May 15th). description: From 15 June 2020, the Federal Ministry for Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering the premises of all modes of operation in the catering industry is allowed if certain conditions are met (see [type_business_var]). Conditions have changed when compared to the regulatory situation of May 29. For some facilities, following these rules is not explicitly mandatory (see exceptions section). The policy is slated to end on August 31. UPDATE: From 1 July 2020, opening hours for the admission of customers are extended and now go from 5 am to 1 am the next day. The allocation of seats is no longer required to be carried out by operators or employees. The obligation to wear a face mask for operators and employees (or having appropriate safeguards for social distancing alternatively) whenever there is customer contact is no longer valid. Self-service may now be allowed if hygienic precautions are in place. Catering industry provisions are extended to December 31. UPDATE: From 1 July 2020, opening hours for the admission of customers are extended and now go from 5 am to 1 am the next day. The allocation of seats is no longer required to be carried out by operators or employees. The obligation to wear a face mask for operators and employees (or having appropriate safeguards for social distancing alternatively) whenever there is customer contact is no longer valid. Self-service may now be allowed if hygienic precautions are in place. Catering industry provisions are extended to December 31.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Restriction of business hours (if applicable note the hours of business in text entry),Other condition not specified above (please provide detail in the text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: From 15 June 2020, entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets), sports grounds and the visitor areas of leisure facilities is allowed if social distancing measures are followed (except for pharmacies where face covering measures are to be followed additionally). Furthermore, entering sports grounds is attached to conditions according to § 8, sections 2 to 5 (§ 1, section 1 and § 8, sections 2 to 5 for outdoor sports grounds) of the source document. Entering the premises of the sex trade industry remains to be prohibited. The policy is slated to end on June 30. UPDATE: From 1 July 2020, provisions for pharmacies now only apply to those that are public. Here, face covering may now be foregone if appropriate safeguards are available alternatively. Provisions for outdoor sports grounds are no longer valid. In the context of sports grounds, carrying out sports activities is (in the case of sports where physical contact is common, in the context of clubs ("Vereinen") or on non-public sports grounds) now only attached to the condition of working out and implementing a COVID-19 prevention concept where provisions are narrowed and reformulated (as per § 8, section 2 of the source document) when compared to the regulatory situation before. Provisions for the carrying out of sports activities through top athletes no longer explicitly refer to instances of falling below social distancing provisions. The carrying out of sports activities at airfields is no longer explicitly attached to social distancing conditions. The prohibition of entering the premises of sex trade facilities expired on June 30. Provisions for business premises, sports grounds and leisure facilities are extended to December 31. UPDATE: From 1 July 2020, provisions for pharmacies now only apply to those that are public. Here, face covering may now be foregone if appropriate safeguards are available alternatively. Provisions for outdoor sports grounds are no longer valid. In the context of sports grounds, carrying out sports activities is (in the case of sports where physical contact is common, in the context of clubs ("Vereinen") or on non-public sports grounds) now only attached to the condition of working out and implementing a COVID-19 prevention concept where provisions are narrowed and reformulated (as per § 8, section 2 of the source document) when compared to the regulatory situation before. Provisions for the carrying out of sports activities through top athletes no longer explicitly refer to instances of falling below social distancing provisions. The carrying out of sports activities at airfields is no longer explicitly attached to social distancing conditions. The prohibition of entering the premises of sex trade facilities expired on June 30. Provisions for business premises, sports grounds and leisure facilities are extended to December 31.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Pharmacies") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Other condition not specified above (please provide detail in the text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: In Austria, from July 1st the mandated earlier closing time of 01:00 in the morning for clubs, restaurants and bars will be lifted for events with 100 or fewer people. Places can soon open at 05:00 instead of 06:00 in the morning. Places can soon open at 05:00 instead of 06:00 in the morning. The carrying out of sports activities at airfields is no longer explicitly attached to social distancing conditions. The prohibition of entering the premises of sex trade facilities expired on June 30. Provisions for business premises, sports grounds and leisure facilities are extended to December 31. UPDATE: From 1 July 2020, provisions for pharmacies now only apply to those that are public. Here, face covering may now be foregone if appropriate safeguards are available alternatively. Provisions for outdoor sports grounds are no longer valid. In the context of sports grounds, carrying out sports activities is (in the case of sports where physical contact is common, in the context of clubs ("Vereinen") or on non-public sports grounds) now only attached to the condition of working out and implementing a COVID-19 prevention concept where provisions are narrowed and reformulated (as per § 8, section 2 of the source document) when compared to the regulatory situation before. Provisions for the carrying out of sports activities through top athletes no longer explicitly refer to instances of falling below social distancing provisions. The carrying out of sports activities at airfields is no longer explicitly attached to social distancing conditions. The prohibition of entering the premises of sex trade facilities expired on June 30. Provisions for business premises, sports grounds and leisure facilities are extended to December 31.

description: From 1 July 2020, the Federal Ministry for Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering the premises of all modes of operation in the catering industry is allowed if certain conditions are met (see [type_business_var]). Conditions have changed when compared to the regulatory situation of June 15. For some facilities, following these rules is not explicitly mandatory (see exceptions section). The policy is slated to end on December 31. UPDATE: From 14 September 2020, the consumption of meals and drinks in confined spaces is only allowed when sitting at prescribed places of serving. The obligation to wear a face mask for operators and employees (or having appropriate safeguards for social distancing alternatively) whenever there is costumer contact is reintroduced for confined spaces. UPDATE: From 14 September 2020, the consumption of meals and drinks in confined spaces is only allowed when sitting at prescribed places of serving. The obligation to wear a face mask for operators and employees (or having appropriate safeguards for social distancing alternatively) whenever there is costumer contact is reintroduced for confined spaces.

description: From 24 July 2020, entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets), sports grounds and the visitor areas of leisure facilities is allowed if social distancing measures are followed (except for pharmacies where face covering measures are to be followed additionally). Furthermore, entering sports grounds is attached to conditions according to § 8, sections 2 to 5 of the source document. For business premises, conditions have changed when compared to the regulatory situation of July 3. The policy is slated to end on December 31. UPDATE: From 14 September 2020, the obligation to wear a face mask when entering costumer areas in confined spaces is now valid within all sorts of business premises. This also applies to the entering of sports grounds and leisure facilities. description: From 14 September 2020, the Federal Ministry for Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering the premises of all modes of operation in the catering industry is allowed if certain conditions are met (see [type_business_var]). Conditions have changed when compared to the regulatory situation of July 1. For some facilities, following these rules is not explicitly mandatory (see exceptions section). The policy is slated to end on December 31. UPDATE: From 21 September 2020, the admission of visitor groups is again attached to conditions. They may be admitted if consisting of 10 adults at the maximum in addition to their underage children or minors for whom they have the responsibility, or from the same household. The obligation to wear a face mask now also applies to costumers in confined spaces whenever not at their seat. UPDATE: From 21 September 2020, the admission of visitor groups is again attached to conditions. They may be admitted if consisting of 10 adults at the maximum in addition to their underage children or minors for whom they have the responsibility, or from the same household. The obligation to wear a face mask now also applies to costumers in confined spaces whenever not at their seat.

description: From 14 September 2020, entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets), sports grounds and the visitor areas of leisure facilities is allowed if certain conditions are met (see [type_business_var]). For business premises, sports grounds and leisure facilities, conditions have changed when compared to the regulatory situation of July 24. The policy is slated to end on December 31. UPDATE: From 21 September 2020, the obligation to wear a face mask when entering costumer areas in confined spaces now also includes "connective structures of business premises which are structurally connected" (such as shopping centres) and outdoor markets. Provisions for the carrying out of sports activities through top athletes are slightly relaxed when compared to the regulatory situation before. UPDATE: From 21 September 2020, the obligation to wear a face mask when entering costumer areas in confined spaces now also includes "connective structures of business premises which are structurally connected" (such as shopping centres) and outdoor markets. Provisions for the carrying out of sports activities through top athletes are slightly relaxed when compared to the regulatory situation before.

Conditions have changed when compared to the regulatory situation of September 14. For some facilities, following these rules is not explicitly mandatory (see exceptions section). description: From 21 September 2020, entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets), sports grounds and the visitor areas of leisure facilities is allowed if certain conditions are met (see [type_business_var]). For business premises and sports grounds, conditions have changed when compared to the regulatory situation of September 14. The policy is slated to end on December 31. UPDATE: From 25 October 2020, face covering measures now explicitly do not apply to "wet rooms" in the context of sports grounds. Exceptions to social distancing measures now only apply to sports activities where physical contact is common, to instances in the context of sports activities where shortly falling below minimum distance provisions is typical of the respective sport or to instances of necessary mutual and safety assistance. Additionally, face covering measures now explicitly do not apply to sports activities. UPDATE: From 25 October 2020, face covering measures now explicitly do not apply to "wet rooms" in the context of sports grounds. Exceptions to social distancing measures now only apply to sports activities where physical contact is common, to instances in the context of sports activities where shortly falling below minimum distance provisions is typical of the respective sport or to instances of necessary mutual and safety assistance. Additionally, face covering measures now explicitly do not apply to sports activities. UPDATE: From 25 October 2020, face covering measures now explicitly do not apply to "wet rooms" in the context of sports grounds. Exceptions to social distancing measures now only apply to sports activities where physical contact is common, to instances in the context of sports activities where shortly falling below minimum distance provisions is typical of the respective sport or to instances of necessary mutual and safety assistance. Additionally, face covering measures now explicitly do not apply to sports activities.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Other Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions

description: From 3 November 2020, entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets) is allowed if social distancing, face covering or other infection protection measures are followed (see [type_business_var]). Entering sports grounds for carrying out sports activities is, with exceptions (which are almost the same as has been enacted on May 1, yet, slightly narrowed and relaxed and with the addition of COVID-19 prevention concept provisions), prohibited. Entering leisure facilities for entertaining, amusing or recreational purposes is, with exceptions (which are almost the same as has been enacted on May 1, yet, slightly narrowed and relaxed in general), prohibited. The policy is slated to end on November 30 and replaced by the previous set of policies on December 1.

description: From 7 November 2020, entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets), sports grounds and the visitor areas of leisure facilities is allowed if certain conditions are met (see [type_business_var]). For business premises, sports grounds and leisure facilities, conditions have changed when compared to the regulatory situation of October 25. The policy is slated to end on December 31. UPDATE: From 3 November to 30 November 2020, previous provisions are replaced by temporary and specific protection measures against the spread of COVID-19. For business premises, these are the same as has been enacted on May 1, with the addition that face mask have to be "close-fitting". For sports grounds, there are the same as has been enacted on  May 1, yet, slightly narrowed and relaxed and with the addition of COVID-19 prevention concept provisions. For leisure facilities, these are the same as has been enacted on May 1, yet, slightly narrowed and relaxed in general. These changes are slated to be replaced by the previous set of policies on December 1. UPDATE: From 3 November to 30 November 2020, previous provisions are replaced by temporary and specific protection measures against the spread of COVID-19. description:
From May 29th, hotels and other accomodation facilities can reopen in Austria. Nevertheless, certain control measures have to be insured: 
- Ensure a minimum distance of 1 meter (Place information by means of displays, signs, stands, floor markings or other aids in the entrance areas and at the reception of the accommodation company and etc).
- Design the catering area (Observe guidelines for catering establishments for general information)
- Adapt additional offers (fitness areas and wellness areas, according to their requirements)
- Place recommendations for behavior that are clearly visible to the guest.

From 3rd of November, this policy is no longer valid (hotels must close) UPDATE: From 3rd of November, this policy is no longer valid

description:
As restaurants open up on May 15th, 2020, the Austrian government requires the staff to wear masks. Furthermore, the customers have to wear masks when entering the restaurant until they seated at a table.

description: In Austria, the original policy limited the working time and number of people of restaurants and bars, as well as mandatory masks wearing requirements for customers and personnel existed (from May 15th). Starting on June 15th, people will be able to sit on a restaurant table with more than 4 people (also from different households), masks will be mandatory only for personnel and restaurants and bars can stay opened until 1:00 am in the morning (before until 23:00). UPDATE: Due to a nationwide lockdown on November 3rd, all cafes, bars and restaurants need to close. Only take-away service is allowed.

The policy is slated to end on November 22. UPDATE: From 7 November 2020, it is made explicit that when face covering is required, the face mask needs to be "close-fitting". UPDATE: From 7 November 2020, it is made explicit that when face covering is required, the face mask needs to be "close-fitting".
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Bars") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Restriction of number of customers,Restriction of business hours (if applicable note the hours of business in text entry),Other condition not specified above (please provide detail in the text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: From 11 November 2020, entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets) is allowed if social distancing, face covering or other infection protection measures are followed (see [type_business_var]). Entering sports grounds for carrying out sports activities is, with exceptions, prohibited. Entering leisure facilities for entertaining, amusing or recreational purposes is, with exceptions, prohibited. For business premises, conditions have changed when compared to the regulatory situation of November 3. The policy is slated to end on November 30 and replaced by the previous set of policies on December 1.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Restriction of number of customers,Restriction of business hours (if applicable note the hours of business in text entry),Other condition not specified above (please provide detail in the text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
link: 472. Verordnung: Änderung der COVID-19-Schutzmaßnahmenverordnung – COVID-19- SchuMaV

description: From 3 November 2020, entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets) is allowed if social distancing, face covering or other infection protection measures are followed (see [type_business_var]). Entering sports grounds for carrying out sports activities is, with exceptions (which are almost the same as has been enacted on May 1, yet, slightly narrowed and relaxed and with the addition of COVID-19 prevention concept provisions), prohibited. Entering leisure facilities for entertaining, amusing or recreational purposes is, with exceptions (which are almost the same as has been enacted on May 1, yet, slightly narrowed and relaxed in general), prohibited. The policy is slated to end on November 30 and replaced by the previous set of policies on December 1. UPDATE: From 11 November 2020, trade facilities selling goods are, with few exceptions, required to have opening hours that go from no earlier than the time that has been in place in the last 4 weeks based on the workday that is next to the present policy changes, to 7 pm at the longest. UPDATE: From 11 November 2020, trade facilities selling goods are, with few exceptions, required to have opening hours that go from no earlier than the time that has been in place in the last 4 weeks based on the workday that is next to the present policy changes, to 7 pm at the longest.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential

compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: From 3 November 2020, entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets) is allowed if social distancing, face covering or other infection protection measures are followed (see [type_business_var]). Entering sports grounds for carrying out sports activities is, with exceptions (which are almost the same as has been enacted on May 1, yet, slightly narrowed and relaxed and with the addition of COVID-19 prevention concept provisions), prohibited. Entering leisure facilities for entertaining, amusing or recreational purposes is, with exceptions (which are almost the same as has been enacted on May 1, yet, slightly narrowed and relaxed in general), prohibited. The policy is slated to end on November 30 and replaced by the previous set of policies on December 1. UPDATE: From 11 November 2020, trade facilities selling goods are, with few exceptions, required to have opening hours that go from no earlier than the time that has been in place in the last 4 weeks based on the workday that is next to the present policy changes, to 7 pm at the longest. description: From 11 November 2020, entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets) is allowed if social distancing, face covering or other infection protection measures are followed (see [type_business_var]). Entering sports grounds for carrying out sports activities is, with exceptions, prohibited. Entering leisure facilities for entertaining, amusing or recreational purposes is, with exceptions, prohibited. For business premises, conditions have changed when compared to the regulatory situation of November 3. The policy is slated to end on November 30 and replaced by the previous set of policies on December 1. UPDATE: From 17 November 2020, entering (and driving along) the costumer areas of trade facilities for purchasing goods, service providers for utilizing physical services and leisure facilities for utilizing leisure facility services is, with exceptions, prohibited. Entering the costumer areas of business premises (or outdoor markets) is attached to certain conditions. If possible, services ought to be provided electronically. Exceptions to sports ground restrictions are narrowed when compared to the regulatory situation before. For when athletes are tested SARS-CoV-2-positive, restrictions that follow are relaxed when compared to the regulatory situation before. UPDATE: From 17 November 2020, entering (and driving along) the costumer areas of trade facilities for purchasing goods, service providers for utilizing physical services and leisure facilities for utilizing leisure facility services is, with exceptions, prohibited. Entering the costumer areas of business premises (or outdoor markets) is attached to certain conditions. If possible, services ought to be provided electronically. Exceptions to sports ground restrictions are narrowed when compared to the regulatory situation before. For when athletes are tested SARS-CoV-2-positive, restrictions that follow are relaxed when compared to the regulatory situation before.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: From 23 November 2020, the Federal Ministry for Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering the premises of all modes of operation in the catering industry is allowed if certain conditions are met (see [type_business_var]). Conditions have changed when compared to the regulatory situation of November 7. For some facilities, following these rules is not explicitly mandatory (see exceptions section). The policy is slated to end on December 31.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Restriction of business hours (if applicable note the hours of business in text entry),Other condition not specified above (please provide detail in the text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: From 7 November 2020, the Federal Ministry for Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering the premises of all modes of operation in the catering industry is allowed if certain conditions are met (see [type_business_var]). Conditions have changed when compared to the regulatory situation of November 1. For some facilities, following these rules is not explicitly mandatory (see exceptions section). The policy is slated to end on November 22. UPDATE: From 23 November 2020, provisions for the admission of visitor groups are no longer valid. The remainder of catering industry provisions remains slated to end on December 31. UPDATE: From 23 November 2020, provisions for the admission of visitor groups are no longer valid. description: From 17 November 2020, entering the costumer areas of defined trade or leisure facilities or in the context of defined service provisions is, with exceptions, prohibited. Besides that, entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets) is allowed if certain conditions are met. Entering sports grounds for carrying out sports activities is, with exceptions (which are narrowed when compared to the regulatory situation of November 11), prohibited. The policy is slated to end on December 6. UPDATE: From 27 November 2020, exceptions for bilateral business-related stores (dealings?) ("Geschäfte") now also apply to service providers (for utilizing physical services). Exceptions for the selling of safety and emergency products are differentiated. Conditions for entering the costumer areas of business premises are differentiated with respect to services for education and training purposes. In the context of sports grounds, airports are now, in addition to airfields, also considered sports grounds. UPDATE: From 27 November 2020, exceptions for bilateral business-related stores (dealings?) ("Geschäfte") now also apply to service providers (for utilizing physical services). Exceptions for the selling of safety and emergency products are differentiated. Conditions for entering the costumer areas of business premises are differentiated with respect to services for education and training purposes. In the context of sports grounds, airports are now, in addition to airfields, also considered sports grounds.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: From 7 December 2020, entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets) is allowed if certain conditions are met (which are the same as had been enacted on November 3, yet, significantly extended). Entering sports grounds for carrying out sports activities is, with exceptions (which are mostly the same as had been enacted on November 3, yet, slightly relaxed and differentiated), prohibited. Entering leisure facilities for entertaining, amusing or recreational purposes is, with exceptions (which are almost the same as had been enacted on November 3, yet, slightly differentiated), prohibited. The policy is slated to end on December 23.

description: In Austria, from 7th of December, retail shops (and services, like friseur) can reopen again. The trade will open again from December 7th, the shops may stay open until 7 p.m. at the latest. It is mandatory to wear mouth and nose protection. For customer areas there is a limit of 10 m 2 per customer.

description: From 17 November 2020, entering the costumer areas of defined trade or leisure facilities or in the context of defined service provisions is, with exceptions, prohibited. Besides that, entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets) is allowed if certain conditions are met. Entering sports grounds for carrying out sports activities is, with exceptions (which are narrowed when compared to the regulatory situation of November 11), prohibited. The policy is slated to end on December 6. UPDATE: From 7 December 2020, for business premises, provisions as had been enacted on November 3 are reintroduced with the addition that for shopping centres, provisions related to the space of costumer areas are differentiated, entering connective structures is regulated, consumption of meals and drinks is prohibited, a COVID-19 prevention concept is to be worked out and implemented, exceptions to social distancing measures in the context of services where minimum distance provisions cannot be followed are attached to the condition that in the meantime no meals or drinks are consumed and trade facilities selling goods have, with exceptions, to close at 7 pm at the least. For sports grounds, provisions are the same as had been enacted on November 3, with the exception that restrictions imposed upon athletes following a SARS-CoV-2-positive test are relaxed when compared to before and airfields are no longer explicitly mentioned. For leisure facilities, provisions are the same as had been enacted on November 3, yet, slightly differentiated. UPDATE: From 7 December 2020, for business premises, provisions as had been enacted on November 3 are reintroduced with the addition that for shopping centres, provisions related to the space of costumer areas are differentiated, entering connective structures is regulated, consumption of meals and drinks is prohibited, a COVID-19 prevention concept is to be worked out and implemented, exceptions to social distancing measures in the context of services where minimum distance provisions cannot be followed are attached to the condition that in the meantime no meals or drinks are consumed and trade facilities selling goods have, with exceptions, to close at 7 pm at the least. For sports grounds, provisions are the same as had been enacted on November 3, with the exception that restrictions imposed upon athletes following a SARS-CoV-2-positive test are relaxed when compared to before and airfields are no longer explicitly mentioned. For leisure facilities, provisions are the same as had been enacted on November 3, yet, slightly differentiated.

description: From December 24th, 2020, on, cable cars, gondolas and lifts in Austria can be re-entered for leisure purposes. A capacity restriction of 50% applies in closed rooms, mouth and nose protection is also mandatory in the waiting and boarding areas. The formation of car pools and the use of taxis is only permitted if only two people are seated per row of seats (including the driver). Mouth and nose protection must also be worn. There are exceptions for the transport of kindergarden children or for the transport of people with disabilities, if this is necessary due to the number of passengers and when getting on and off. Public transport can still be used. Mouth and nose protection must be worn in public transport and at subway stations, bus stops, airports, etc. and a distance of one meter must be kept.

description:
Starting from February 8, 2021, the following applies on the transportation in Austria:

1. cable cars, gondolas & climbing aids: In closed and coverable vehicles only 50% of the transport capacity may be used, ie only half as many people may be transported. In addition, an FFP2 mask without an exhalation valve (or mask of the same or higher quality) must be worn. Operators have to implement appropriate prevention concepts based on the risk analysis and the state of the art.    

2. In motor vehicles (private car, taxi, Uber) a maximum of two people per row of seats may be carried (exception: shared household). In addition, an FFP2 mask (or mask of the same or higher quality) must be worn.

3. In other transportation vehicles and surrounding like metro, airport, etc.: An FFP2 mask (or mask of the same or higher quality) must be worn and a safety distance of at least 2 meters must be kept from others.

description: Announced on March 15, 2021, the federal state of Vorarlberg states the opening of the gastronomy - starting on March 15, 2021 -  with some strict conditions: when entering the restaurant a negative antigen test or a negative PCR test must be presented. Also, guests are required to register to facilitate contact tracing; there must be a distance of two meters between tables, more than four people are not allowed to sit at a table unless they live in the same household; mask compulsory and food and drinks may only be consumed while seated.

description: Announced on April 2, 2021, the national government of Austria stated that from April 1st to April 11, 2021, stricter measures apply for the federal states of Burgenland, Lower Austria and Vienna. A 24-hour order to stay at home (with exceptions) is in place. The trade is closed (everyday goods such as grocery stores and pharmacies are exceptions). Click & Collect is possible for all stores. The goods must be handed over outdoors.

description: On July 1, 2021, Austria announced that, beginning from July 3, 2021, any trucks that are over 7.5 t would be prohibited from driving "on the A 4 eastern motorway from the Schwechat junction to the Nickelsdorf state border in both directions on all Saturdays from 3 July 2021 up to and including 28 August 2021 between 8 a.m. and 3 p.m." Certain exceptions to the traffic ban applies, including "to and from the districts of Neusiedl am See, Eisenstadt, Eisenstadt-Umgebung, Rust, Mattersburg, Bruck an der Leitha, Gänserndorf and Korneuburg." Hotels are open to the public with a negative COVID-19 test upon arrival or proof of vaccination/past infection. For nightclubs,  a negative COVID-19 test upon arrival or proof of vaccination is required. The end date is undetermined. This will be monitored by businesses and additional law support if necessary.

description: From February 19th, the requirement for proof of 2G will no longer apply in restaurants, cafes, bars or hotels. This will be replaced with a 3G requirement, meaning that people without 2G can show a recent negative Covid test to enter these venues. To enter restaurants, cafes and bars, PCR tests will only be valid for 48 hours after the time of the test, but in all other areas (eg. for entering workplaces), PCR tests will remain valid for 72 hours (note that Vienna has a blanket rule of 48-hour validity).
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
institution_cat: Non-Essential Businesses
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Negative COVID-19 Test,Proof of COVID-19 Vaccination,3G: Must be either (i) vaccinated, (ii) have a valid COVID-19 negative test within a certain time frame, or (iii) recovered from COVID-19

description:
On 23 February 2022, Austria lifted the 3G requirement for workplaces
Workplaces in Austria will soon lift the requirement for employees to show proof of vaccination, recovery or a negative test as the country relaxes its Covid measures.
The 3G requirement at work has been in place since November 1st and applies to all workplaces where you can’t rule out coming into close contact with others, whether that’s at your desk, at reception or in a kitchen or common area.
Penalties of up to €500 can be issued to employees, and up to €3600 for employers that violate the law.

description: Effective March 5th, the midnight curfew for restaurants has been lifted as nightclubs and apres-ski venues are allowed to reopen. description: On 26 July 2022 Labour minister Martin Kocher (ÖVP) announced a restriction and regulation of businesses that risk groups should be protected, and a specific ordinance is being prepared for workplaces where there are people at risk. Kocher said that companies will be able to work out measures such as work-from-home schemes for people at risk. Additionally, workers that belong to vulnerable groups could be exempted from work by presenting a “risk certificate”.

description: On Nov 22nd, 2021 Austria announced that Hospitals and nursing homes will remain open throughout the lockdown, but with stricter rules on visitors (restriction and regulation of government services). Any visitor must adhere to the 2G+ rule, meaning they need proof of vaccination or recovery and a recent negative PCR test. There are also limits on visitor numbers: one visitor per patient per week in hospitals and two visitors per resident per day in nursing homes, though for minors and some especially vulnerable people these limits can be increased.

compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
link: Privatwohnungen sind von der Regelung nicht betroffen. „Soziale Kontakte müssen reduziert werden“, so der Kanzler. Sämtliche Veranstaltungen seien daher im Privaten mit zehn Personen beschränkt. Betroffen davon sind auch Gruppenkurse etwa in Fitnessstudios und Tanzschulen. Professionelle Veranstaltungen im Innen- und Außenbereich sind allerdings weiterhin möglich - unter den auch aktuell geltenden Bestimmungen. Ausgenommen von der Zehn-Personen-Begrenzung sind Begräbnisse, Hochzeiten aber nicht. In der Gastronomie dürfen künftig nur noch zehn Personen an einem Tisch sitzen. Konsumiert werden darf nur noch am Tisch. Und: In Lokalen muss künftig auch der Gast überall ein Mund-Nasen-Schutz tragen - außer er sitzt am Platz.; https://www.diepresse.com/5868553/private-treffen-im-innenbereich-ab-montag-auf-zehn-personen-beschraenkt

description:
With election day approaching fast in Vienna, safety measures are being put in place for voting in the Vienna election on October 11, 2020.
Voters can visit one of 1,494 voting stations between 7:00 and 15:00 on October 11.
Facemasks must be worn inside the voting stations and voters are requested to bring their own pen with them to fill out the ballot.
Postal ballots (also called absentee ballots, Wahlkarte) can already be mailed in or submitted. Voters who have not received one in the mail can also pick it up at the Magistrate for your district.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Annually recurring event allowed to occur with certain conditions

description:
Announced on June 2, 2021, the national government of Austria stated that starting on June 2, 2021, gatherings of less than 10 people are permitted without notification or approval. 

From 11 people, the 3-G rule applies, and a report to the local health authority as well as mask wearing are required for both indoors and outdoors. Serving drinks and food are not permitted. This rule applies to weddings, garden parties and similar events.

From 51 people, only events with assigned seats are permitted. These must be approved by the local health authority. The maximum limit is 1,500 people indoors and 3,000 outdoors.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Announced on June 10, 2021, the national government of Austria stated that starting on June 10, 2021 and ending on June 30, 2021, gatherings up to 8 people plus children are permitted indoors and up to 16 people plus children are permitted outdoors. No distance and mask requirement for up to 8 people and meetings of less than 17 people are permitted without notification or approval.
From 17 people, the 3-G rule applies, and a report to the local health authority is required. In addition, an FFP2 mask must be worn indoors. Serving drinks and serving food is not permitted. This rule applies to weddings, garden parties and similar events.
From 51 people, only events with assigned seats are permitted. These must be approved by the local health authority. The maximum limit is 1,500 people indoors and 3,000 outdoors. 75% of the seating capacity may be occupied.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: All Recreational or commercial events allowed to occur with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 14 April 2022, Austria’s capital Vienna is removing its main restrictions on mass gatherings. Starting from April 16th, 2022, people will no longer need to present proof that they are vaccinated or recovered from the disease (2G rule) to enter bars and restaurants. The 2G rules are being dropped in all areas, including gastronomy, sports, and hospitals, the secretary said. The state capital is also following federal reopening steps and dropping the FFP2 mask requirement for non-essential retail, including shops and gyms.

Entering leisure facilities for entertaining, amusing or recreational purposes is, with exceptions, prohibited for visitors. The policy is slated to end on June 30.

description: Announced on April 17, 2020, the state of Styria opens federal cultural institutions such as libraries (18.05), various museums by 01.05, and Galleries. The opening of cultural institutions starts on May 1st, 2020 with some conditions such as disinfection of hands, wear mouth and nose protection and the required distance regulations.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Public libraries
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
